ai_summary: Section 6.1 outlines the benefits of Total and Permanent Disability (TPD) Insurance based on whether the policy is structured inside or outside of superannuation. Key benefits such as the TPD Benefit, Cover Continuation Benefit, and Inflation Protection Benefit are available in both structures. However, certain benefits like the Advanced Payment Benefit, Financial Planning Benefit, and Grief Counselling Benefit are exclusive to policies outside superannuation. Notably, the Death Benefit is only available with stand-alone TPD policies within TAL Super. Optional benefits, including Death Buy-Back and Double TPD options, are accessible in both structures, while the Business Insurance Option is limited to policies outside superannuation.

content:
The TPD Benefit is payable if the Life Insured becomes Totally and Permanently Disabled. The following definitions of Total and Permanent Disability are available under the Policy:
• ‘Any Occupation’
• ‘Own Occupation’ or
• ‘Activities of Daily Living’
The definition applicable to the Life Insured will be shown in the Policy Schedule. Where Superlink is indicated in your Policy Schedule the ‘Own Occupation’ definition of TPD insurance applies, however claims are first assessed using the ‘Any Occupation’ definition and the SIS definition of Permanent Incapacity. A TPD Benefit is not payable if the Life insured dies within 14 days after suffering the Sickness or Injury that directly or indirectly caused the Total and Permanent Disability.
ai_summary: The TPD Benefit provides financial support if the Life Insured becomes Totally and Permanently Disabled, with definitions of disability categorized as ‘Any Occupation,’ ‘Own Occupation,’ or ‘Activities of Daily Living,’ as specified in the Policy Schedule. For policies indicating Superlink, the ‘Own Occupation’ definition applies, but claims are initially assessed under the ‘Any Occupation’ standard and the SIS definition of Permanent Incapacity. Notably, the TPD Benefit is not payable if the Life Insured passes away within 14 days of the Sickness or Injury that led to the disability.

content: Not available when structured through superannuation. If the Life Insured suffers the Loss of use of a Single Limb (permanent) or the Loss of Sight in One Eye (permanent), an advanced payment of 25% of the Benefit Amount, up to a maximum payment of $500,000 will be payable. This is payable only once and the TPD Benefit Amount will be reduced by the amount paid for the Loss of use a Single Limb (permanent) or the Loss of Sight in One Eye (permanent). The advanced payment will only be paid if the condition or the circumstances leading to the claim occurs after the Plan start date.
ai_summary: The Advanced Payment Benefit under TPD Insurance provides a one-time payment of 25% of the Benefit Amount, up to a maximum of $500,000, for the permanent loss of use of a single limb or the permanent loss of sight in one eye. This benefit is not available if the insurance is structured through superannuation and will reduce the overall TPD Benefit Amount. Eligibility for this payment requires that the qualifying condition occurs after the start date of the plan.

content: Only available when the policy is structured through TAL Super. Not available when Attached or Linked to Life Insurance or Critical Illness insurance. If the TPD Benefit has not been paid and the Life Insured dies we will pay the lesser of $10,000 or the TPD Benefit Amount.
ai_summary: The Death Benefit under the TPD Insurance is exclusively available when the policy is structured through TAL Super and is not applicable if linked to Life Insurance or Critical Illness insurance. In the event of the Life Insured's death, if the TPD Benefit has not been paid, the payout will be the lesser of $10,000 or the TPD Benefit Amount.

Under the Cover Continuation Benefit for TPD insurance, policyholders can apply to maintain coverage under the 'Any Occupation' definition before their 65th birthday, provided certain conditions are met, including having an applicable occupation class (AAA, AA+, or AA) and submitting a written application within 30 days of the policy anniversary. The maximum benefit amount is capped at $1,000,000, premiums may increase, and any Death Buy-Back and Double TPD Options will cease. Eligibility requires the insured to be engaged in a Gainful Occupation in the specified classes prior to becoming Totally and Permanently Disabled.

content:
Benefit Options listed below only apply if indicated in your Policy Schedule.

Death Buy-Back Option
If we pay 100% of the TPD insurance Benefit Amount, TPD insurance will end. When this occurs, under the Death Buy-Back Option, you can buy-back Life insurance on the Life Insured.

The amount of cover you may repurchase is the amount of the TPD insurance Benefit Amount paid. The Death Buy-Back Option can be exercised without having to provide evidence of health, occupation, income or pastimes, or any other Underwriting information.

You must notify us in writing of your intention to exercise the Death Buy-Back Option. Notification must occur during the 30 days following the 12 month anniversary of the date we were notified formally of a claim in accordance with our claim requirements (see Section 9.2 Claims), and in relation to a claim which was subsequently paid. Any further requirements must be submitted to us within 30 days of the date we received your notification or the Death Buy-Back Option will expire.

If payment of the claim occurs more than 12 months after the formal notification was made to us, reinstatement will be available for 30 days from the date of payment. If you fail to exercise the Death Buy-Back during this 30 day period, the Death Buy-Back Option will expire.

The Death Buy-Back Option will expire if not exercised before the Policy anniversary before the Life Insured's 65th birthday.

The premium for the repurchased Life insurance will be calculated using our standard premium rates for the age of the Life Insured at the time the option is exercised and will take into account any extra premiums charged and special provisions that apply to the Life insurance Plan for the Life Insured.

The repurchased Life insurance will not be eligible for increases under the:
* Inflation Protection Benefit,
* Guaranteed Future Insurability Benefit, or
* Business Insurance Option (if applicable).

The Death Buy-Back Option is not available unless TPD insurance is Attached or Linked to Life insurance.

The Death Buy-Back Option does not apply where 'Double TPD' or 'Double Critical Illness' is shown in your Policy Schedule.
ai_summary: The Death Buy-Back Option allows you to repurchase Life insurance equal to the TPD insurance Benefit Amount paid, without providing additional underwriting information, provided you notify the insurer in writing within 30 days following the 12-month anniversary of a claim payment. This option expires if not exercised before the Policy anniversary prior to the Life Insured's 65th birthday, and the premium will be based on the Life Insured's age at the time of repurchase, excluding certain benefits. The option is only available if TPD insurance is linked to Life insurance and is not applicable in cases of 'Double TPD' or 'Double Critical Illness.'

content:
The Double TPD Option is only available if TPD insurance is Attached or Linked to Life insurance.

If ‘Double TPD’ is indicated in your Policy Schedule, and the TPD Benefit becomes payable:

* the Life insurance Benefit will not be reduced;
* future premiums due in respect of that part of the Life insurance Benefit Amount equal to the TPD Benefit paid will be waived;
* the Life insurance Benefit Amount equal to the TPD Benefit Amount paid will continue until the Life insurance Plan end date; and
* in the event cover is transferred to non-superannuation ownership, future premiums due in respect of that part of the Life insurance Benefit Amount equal to the TPD Benefit paid will be waived until the Life insurance Plan end date.

The Life insurance will not be eligible for increases under the Inflation Protection Benefit, Guaranteed Future Insurability Benefit or Business Insurance Option (if applicable), after the TPD Benefit becomes payable.

This Option will expire on the Policy anniversary before the Life Insured’s 65th birthday.
ai_summary: The Double TPD Option is available only when TPD insurance is linked to Life insurance. If activated, it ensures that the Life insurance Benefit remains intact and waives future premiums equivalent to the TPD Benefit paid, continuing until the policy's end date. However, after the TPD Benefit is claimed, the Life insurance will not qualify for increases under certain benefits, and this option expires on the policy anniversary prior to the Life Insured's 65th birthday.

Superlink TPD offers a dual TPD insurance structure, combining an 'Own Occupation' definition outside of superannuation with an 'Any Occupation' definition within superannuation. Two linked policies are issued—one to the superannuation trustee and the other to the policyholder—ensuring that benefits, loadings, and exclusions remain consistent across both. Claims are first evaluated under the superannuation policy's definitions; if unmet, the non-superannuation policy's 'Own Occupation' definition is used. Notably, if one policy is canceled, the other will also be canceled unless otherwise notified, and the total benefits from both policies cannot exceed that of a single TPD policy. Policy Schedules will specify when Superlink

content:
Income Protection only applies under this Policy if ‘Income Protection Plan’ is indicated in your Policy Schedule.

Income Protection is available as ‘Super’, ‘Standard’, or ‘Premier’. The type applicable is shown in your Policy Schedule. Income Protection ‘Super’ is only available through superannuation. Income Protection ‘Standard’ and ‘Premier’ are not available through superannuation.

Income Protection Standard and Premier can be Superlinked to an Income Protection Super Policy.

Income Protection Super, Standard and Premier conditions are set out in this section of this Policy Document.

Benefits available under Income Protection ‘Super’ conditions are summarised in Section 7.1 of this Policy Document.

When we refer to a benefit payment, we mean a benefit payment which is paid in accordance with the terms and conditions of this Policy. We will not make a benefit payment if an exclusion applies. Exclusions are explained in Section 8 of this Policy Document. You must also satisfy our claim requirements explained in Section 9.2 of this Policy Document.
ai_summary: Income Protection coverage under this Policy is contingent upon the designation of 'Income Protection Plan' in the Policy Schedule, with options available as 'Super', 'Standard', or 'Premier.' 'Super' is exclusively accessible through superannuation, while 'Standard' and 'Premier' can be linked to an Income Protection Super Policy. Detailed conditions and benefits for each type are outlined in this section, with specific benefits for 'Super' summarized in Section 7.1. Benefit payments are contingent upon adherence to the Policy's terms, with exclusions detailed in Section 8 and claim requirements specified in Section 9.2.

content:
1 Only available for healthcare professionals.
2 Only available for AA+ occupations as specified in the Policy Schedule.
These benefits are described as follows.
ai_summary: Section 7.1 of the Income Protection policy outlines that benefits are exclusively available to healthcare professionals and are limited to those in AA+ occupations as specified in the Policy Schedule.

content:
If the occupation class of the Life Insured is AAA, AA+, AA, A, BBB, BB+, BB or B, as specified in the Policy Schedule, the Total Disability Benefit will be paid when:
• the Life Insured has been either Totally Disabled or Partially Disabled for the Waiting Period; and
• at the end of the Waiting Period the Life Insured remains Totally Disabled.
If the occupation class of the Life Insured is SRA as specified in the Policy Schedule, the Total Disability Benefit will be paid when:
• the Life Insured has been Totally Disabled for 14 consecutive days during the Waiting Period;
• the Life Insured is Totally Disabled or Partially Disabled for the balance of the Waiting Period; and
• at the end of the Waiting Period the Life Insured remains Totally Disabled.
The amount paid will be the Benefit Amount, subject to any Income Protection Adjustments (set out in Section 8 of this Policy Document).
The Total Disability Benefit:
• starts to accrue after the Waiting Period ends;
• is paid monthly in arrears; and
• will stop on the earlier of the following events:
– the Life Insured no longer being Totally Disabled;
– the end of the Benefit Period; or
– the Plan end date.
ai_summary: The Total Disability Benefit is available for Life Insured individuals based on their occupation class, with specific conditions for AAA to B classes requiring either Total or Partial Disability during the Waiting Period, and SRA class requiring 14 consecutive days of Total Disability. The benefit amount, subject to adjustments, begins accruing after the Waiting Period and is paid monthly in arrears, ceasing upon the Life Insured's recovery, the end of the Benefit Period, or the Plan end date.

content:
Where Income Protection 'Standard' or 'Premier' has been selected and the occupation class of the Life Insured is AAA, AA+, AA, A, BBB, BB+, BB or B (as specified in the Policy Schedule) the Partial Disability Benefit will be paid when:
• the Life Insured has been either Totally Disabled or Partially Disabled for the Waiting Period; and
• at the conclusion of the Waiting Period the Life Insured remains Partially Disabled.
Where Income Protection 'Super' has been selected, or the occupation class of the Life Insured is SRA (as specified in the Policy Schedule), the Partial Disability Benefit will be paid when:
• the Life Insured has been Totally Disabled for 14 consecutive days during the Waiting Period;
• the Life Insured is either Totally Disabled or Partially Disabled for the balance of the Waiting Period; and
• at the conclusion of the Waiting Period the Life Insured remains Partially Disabled.
The Partial Disability Benefit paid will be:
A – B × the Benefit Amount
A
subject to any adjustments, where
A = the Life Insured’s Pre-Disability Earnings; and
B = the Life Insured’s Earnings during the period of Partial Disability
If Income Protection 'Super' or 'Standard' is shown in your Policy Schedule, and the Life Insured is not working to their full capacity or is suffering a loss of income for reasons other than Sickness or Injury, 'B' will be calculated on the Earnings for which it would be reasonable for the Life Insured to earn. We will take into account all medical and other appropriate evidence.
If Income Protection 'Premier' is shown in your Policy Schedule, we will deem the loss to be 100% if the Life Insured is unable to work more than ten hours per week in his or her Own Occupation or any Gainful Occupation and his or her Earnings are less than their Pre-Disability Earnings.
ai_summary: The Partial Disability Benefit under Income Protection policies ('Standard', 'Premier', or 'Super') is payable when the Life Insured has been Totally or Partially Disabled for the Waiting Period and remains Partially Disabled thereafter, with specific conditions based on occupation class. The benefit amount is calculated using a formula that considers Pre-Disability Earnings and current Earnings during Partial Disability, with adjustments made for non-disability-related income loss. For 'Premier' policyholders, a loss is deemed 100% if the insured cannot work more than ten hours weekly in their Own or any Gainful Occupation, and their Earnings fall below Pre-Disability levels.

The Partial Disability Benefit begins after the Waiting Period and is paid monthly in arrears, ceasing upon the Life Insured's recovery from Partial Disability, the end of the Benefit Period, or the Plan end date. Notably, if Partial Disability follows a Total Disability period without interruption, the Waiting Period does not reset.

Subheading: Benefit Amount for 'to age 70' Benefit Period
content:
If the Benefit Period selected is ‘to age 70’ and the Life Insured’s Total Disability or Partial Disability starts after the Life Insured’s 65th birthday, the Benefit Amount payable for the duration of the claim will be reduced based on the Life Insured’s age at the start of the Waiting Period according to the following table:

Age Attained | % of Benefit Amount paid
---|---
66 | 80%
67 | 60%
68 | 40%
69 | 20%
ai_summary: For a 'to age 70' Benefit Period, if Total or Partial Disability begins after the Life Insured turns 65, the Benefit Amount will be reduced based on age at the start of the Waiting Period: 80% if aged 66, 60% if 67, 40% if 68, and 20% if 69.

content:
At each Policy anniversary, we will increase the Benefit Amount by the greater of the Indexation Factor and three per cent.
This increase will occur on each Policy anniversary unless:
• you tell us the Inflation Protection Benefit is not to apply to your Plan;
• premiums are being waived under the Waiver of Premium Benefit; or
• cover is suspended under the Premium Pause Benefit.
In the event of an increase, a new premium will be calculated to incorporate the increased Benefit Amount. This calculation will also take into account the Life Insured’s age and premium type, (ie stepped or level premium). We will not take into account any changes in the Life Insured’s health, occupation, income or pastimes.
Increases under the Inflation Protection Benefit will cease on the earlier of:
• when you ask us not to increase the Benefit Amount; or
• the Policy anniversary before the Life Insured’s 65th birthday.
ai_summary: The Inflation Protection Benefit increases the Benefit Amount at each Policy anniversary by the greater of the Indexation Factor or three percent, unless the policyholder opts out, premiums are waived, or cover is suspended. A new premium will be calculated based on the increased Benefit Amount, considering the Life Insured’s age and premium type, but not their health or occupation changes. Increases will stop either upon the policyholder's request or the anniversary before the Life Insured turns 65.

content: If the Life Insured dies we will pay a lump sum equal to six times the monthly Benefit Amount, to a maximum of $50,000.
ai_summary: In the event of the Life Insured's death, a lump sum payment will be made equal to six times the monthly Benefit Amount, capped at a maximum of $50,000. This provision ensures financial support for beneficiaries following the insured's passing.

content: If the Life Insured becomes Totally Disabled or Partially Disabled as a result of separate and distinct Sicknesses or Injuries, only one benefit is payable under Income Protection and this will be the benefit that provides the highest payment.
ai_summary: In the event that the Life Insured experiences Total or Partial Disability due to multiple distinct Sicknesses or Injuries, the Income Protection policy stipulates that only one benefit will be paid, specifically the one with the highest monetary value.

content:
If a claim has been paid under the Total Disability Benefit or the Partial Disability Benefit, we understand in certain circumstances the condition may reoccur from the same or a related cause during the term of the Plan. Where this happens within 12 months of the initial claim ending, the reoccurrence will be considered a continuation of the initial claim. While the Waiting Period will not be reapplied, all periods of benefit payment will be added together for the purpose of assessing the maximum Benefit Period.

If the Benefit Period is one, two or five years, this is the most we will pay for any one or related Sickness or Injury during the term of the Plan.

If the Life Insured has both:
• income protection cover provided through a superannuation fund with a two-year Benefit Period; and
• TAL Income Protection with a two-year Waiting Period and a Benefit Period of five years, to age 65 or 70,

and claims under the Recurrent Disability Benefit on the superannuation Policy, we will use the original start date of the claim for calculation of benefit entitlements under Income Protection.
ai_summary: The Recurrent Disability Benefit allows for a continuation of claims under the Total or Partial Disability Benefits if a related condition reoccurs within 12 months of the initial claim's end, without reapplying the Waiting Period. Benefit payments from the initial and recurrent claims will be aggregated to assess the maximum Benefit Period, which is capped at one, two, or five years for any related Sickness or Injury. Additionally, if the Life Insured has income protection through both a superannuation fund and TAL Income Protection, the original claim start date will be used for calculating benefit entitlements under the Income Protection policy.

content:
Under the Elective Surgery Benefit, the Life Insured will be considered Totally Disabled due to Sickness when Total Disability results from:
• surgery to transplant part of the Life Insured’s body to someone else;
• surgery to improve the Life Insured’s appearance; or
• elective surgery performed on the advice of a Medical Practitioner.

The Elective Surgery Benefit will not apply if the surgery took place:
• within six months after the Plan start date;
• within six months after the date of an applied for increase but only in respect of the increase amount; and
• within six months after the most recent date we agreed to reinstate the Plan.

Where Income Protection Super has been selected (as indicated in the Policy Schedule), the Life Insured must also satisfy the SIS definition of Temporary Incapacity or Permanent Incapacity.
ai_summary: The Elective Surgery Benefit under the Income Protection policy considers the Life Insured Totally Disabled due to Sickness for specific elective surgeries, including organ transplants, cosmetic procedures, and surgeries advised by a Medical Practitioner. However, this benefit is not applicable if the surgery occurs within six months of the Plan's start date, an increase in coverage, or the most recent reinstatement date. Additionally, if Income Protection Super is selected, the Life Insured must meet the SIS definitions of Temporary or Permanent Incapacity.

content:
The Waiver of Premium Benefit applies when Total Disability or Partial Disability payments have accrued. This includes payments under the Scheduled Injury Benefit and Critical Illness Option. In this instance, the daily proportion of premiums due in respect of the Life Insured under Income Protection must continue to be paid, but will later be refunded as a credit to the Policy Owner. The premium for all other benefits under the Policy must continue to be paid.

The Waiver of Premium Benefit:
• starts to accrue from the first day of the Waiting Period;
• applies immediately after the Waiting Period for any premiums paid during the Waiting Period and monthly in arrears for subsequent premiums; and
• will stop on the earlier of;
– the Life Insured no longer being Totally Disabled or Partially Disabled; or
– the end of the Benefit Period.

When Superlink IP is selected, the Waiver of Premium Benefit will apply for both Policies.
ai_summary: The Waiver of Premium Benefit allows for the refund of premiums paid during periods of Total or Partial Disability, including those under the Scheduled Injury Benefit and Critical Illness Option. It begins accruing from the first day of the Waiting Period and applies to premiums paid during this period, continuing monthly in arrears thereafter. The benefit ceases when the Life Insured is no longer disabled or at the end of the Benefit Period. Premiums for other policy benefits must still be paid, and if Superlink IP is selected, the Waiver applies to both Policies.

content:
The Bed Confinement Benefit will be paid when the Life Insured is:
• Totally Disabled; and
• Bed Confined during the Waiting Period for 72 consecutive hours or more.

The amount to be paid will be 1/30th of the Benefit Amount for each day of Bed Confinement.

The Bed Confinement Benefit:
• starts to accrue from the first day of the Waiting Period;
• is paid monthly in arrears; and
• will stop on the earlier of the following events:
– the end of the Waiting Period;
– the Plan end date;
– the end of Bed Confinement; or
– payments equalling three times the Benefit Amount having occurred.

If the Life Insured is eligible for payment under the Bed Confinement Benefit, Accident Benefit Option, Critical Illness Option or the Scheduled Injury Benefit, only the greater of these benefit payments will be paid.
ai_summary: The Bed Confinement Benefit provides financial support when the Life Insured is totally disabled and confined to bed for at least 72 consecutive hours during the Waiting Period. The benefit accrues from the first day of the Waiting Period and is paid monthly in arrears at a rate of 1/30th of the Benefit Amount for each day of confinement, ceasing upon the end of the Waiting Period, Plan end date, end of confinement, or after payments reach three times the Benefit Amount. If eligible for multiple benefits, only the highest payment will be issued.

content:
Only available through Income Protection Standard or Premier.
The Family Support Benefit will be paid when the Life Insured is Totally Disabled and Bed Confined for 28 consecutive days, and:
• an Immediate Family Member of the Life Insured stops being in a Gainful Occupation to provide care and assistance to the Life Insured; or
• the treating Medical Practitioner recommends a Registered Nurse is employed to provide care and assistance to the Life Insured.
If the Family Support Benefit applies, the monthly amount paid will be the lesser of the following:
• $5,000;
• the Benefit Amount; or
• the loss of earnings suffered by the Immediate Family Member, or the cost incurred of the Registered Nurse deemed necessary, less amounts reimbursed from elsewhere.
The Family Support Benefit:
• starts to accrue when the Life Insured has been Totally Disabled for 28 consecutive days and the loss or expenditure is incurred;
• is paid monthly in arrears; and
• will stop on the earlier of:
– the Life Insured no longer being Totally Disabled;
– the end of the Benefit Period;
– the Plan end date; or
– three months Family Support Benefit having been paid for any one Total Disability.
ai_summary: The Family Support Benefit, available through Income Protection Standard or Premier, provides financial assistance when the Life Insured is Totally Disabled and Bed Confined for 28 consecutive days. It is payable if an Immediate Family Member ceases Gainful Occupation to care for the Life Insured or if a Medical Practitioner recommends hiring a Registered Nurse. The benefit amount is capped at $5,000, the Benefit Amount, or the loss of earnings/care costs incurred, minus any reimbursements. This benefit accrues after 28 days of Total Disability, is paid monthly in arrears, and ceases upon the Life Insured's recovery, the end of the Benefit Period, the Plan end date, or after three months of payments for a single Total Disability.

content:
Only available through Income Protection Standard or Premier.
The Housekeeper Benefit will be paid when:
• the Life Insured is Totally Disabled for 28 consecutive days;
• the Life Insured is Bed Confined at the Life Insured’s usual place of residence; and
• the Life Insured needs to rely totally on another person, other than an Immediate Family Member, for housekeeping.
If the Housekeeper Benefit applies, the monthly amount paid is the lesser of the following:
• $5,000;
• the Benefit Amount; or
• the cost of the housekeeper, less amounts reimbursed from elsewhere.
ai_summary: The Housekeeper Benefit, available through Income Protection Standard or Premier, provides financial support when the Life Insured is Totally Disabled for 28 consecutive days, is Bed Confined at home, and requires assistance with housekeeping from someone other than an Immediate Family Member. The benefit amount paid monthly is limited to the lesser of $5,000, the Benefit Amount, or the actual cost of the housekeeper after any reimbursements.

The Housekeeper Benefit under the Income Protection policy begins after the Life Insured has been Totally Disabled for 28 consecutive days and is paid monthly in arrears. This benefit ceases upon the occurrence of several events, including the Life Insured's recovery from Total Disability, the conclusion of the Benefit Period, the Plan end date, or after six months of payments, provided the Life Insured is no longer Bed Confined or reliant on another person for housekeeping.

content:
Only available through Income Protection Standard or Premier.
If the Life Insured suffers a Scheduled Injury listed in the following table, the Benefit Amount will be payable from the date of injury for the lesser of:
• the Payment Period shown; and
• the Benefit Period.
If the Life Insured suffers more than one Scheduled Injury in a single event, only one Scheduled Injury Benefit will be paid and it will be based on the Scheduled Injury with the greatest payment period.
You have the choice of having benefits paid in advance for the first six months of any payment period, and monthly in arrears thereafter, or monthly in arrears for the entire payment period.
The Scheduled Injury Benefit will stop on the earlier of the following events:
• the expiry of the Payment Period shown;
• the end of the Benefit Period; or
• the Plan end date.
At the expiry of the Payment Period, the Life Insured may be eligible for other benefits based on the appropriate Plan conditions being satisfied.
If the Life Insured is eligible for payment under the Bed Confinement Benefit, Accident Benefit Option, Critical Illness Option or the Scheduled Injury Benefit, only the greater of these benefit payments will be paid.
The Total Disability Benefit and the Partial Disability Benefit are not payable during any period that the Scheduled Injury Benefit is being paid.
ai_summary: The Scheduled Injury Benefit, available through Income Protection Standard or Premier, provides a Benefit Amount for listed injuries from the date of injury, limited to the lesser of the specified Payment Period or Benefit Period. If multiple injuries occur from a single event, only the highest payment period injury will qualify for benefits. Payments can be received in advance for the first six months or monthly in arrears thereafter. The benefit ceases upon the end of the Payment Period, Benefit Period, or Plan end date, with potential eligibility for other benefits thereafter. The Scheduled Injury Benefit supersedes other benefits like the Bed Confinement Benefit or Accident Benefit Option, and Total or Partial Disability Benefits are not payable during its duration.

content:
Scheduled Injury | Payment period (in months)
---|---
Paralysis (permanent) | 60
Loss of use or Loss of:
* both feet or hands or sight in both eyes | 24
* any combination of two of, a hand, a foot and sight in one eye | 24
* one leg or arm | 18
* one foot or hand or sight in one eye | 12
* the thumb and index finger of the same hand | 6
Fracture of the:
* thigh or pelvis | 3
* leg (talus, tibia or fibula only), kneecap, upper arm (humerus or scapula only) or jaw | 2
* forearm (radius or ulna only), collarbone (clavicle only) or heel | 1
* wrist/carpal bones (excluding metacarpal and phalanges) | 1
* vertebrae | 1
* skull (excluding bones of the nose and face) | 2

Loss means the total and permanent loss of:
* the use of the hand or foot from the wrist or ankle joint;
* the use of the arm or leg from the elbow or knee joint;
* the use of the thumb and index finger from the first phalange joint; or
* sight, to the extent that visual acuity in the eye, on a Snellen Scale after correction by a suitable lens, is less than 6/60 or to the extent that the visual field is reduced to 20 degrees or less of arc.

Fracture means a bone fracture requiring immobilisation with the application of a pin, traction, plaster cast or an immobilising device by a Medical Practitioner.

Immobilisation is not required for fracture of the jaw, vertebrae or skull.
ai_summary: The Scheduled Injury Benefit under the Income Protection policy outlines payment periods for various permanent injuries, with benefits ranging from 60 months for permanent paralysis to 6 months for the loss of the thumb and index finger of the same hand. Specific durations are also assigned for fractures, with payments of up to 3 months for severe fractures like those of the thigh or pelvis, and 1 month for less severe fractures such as those of the wrist or vertebrae. Loss is defined as total and permanent impairment of function, while fractures must require immobilization by a medical professional, except for certain cases like jaw or skull fractures.

content:
Only available through Income Protection Super.

Under the Superannuation Pause Benefit, you may apply to temporarily suspend the premiums and Plan for up to 12 consecutive months if the Life Insured has ceased working in a Gainful Occupation for reasons other than Sickness or Injury. You must provide us with evidence acceptable to us that the Life Insured is stopping work.

This means that:
* no premiums are due, no Benefit Amount is payable and no indexation occurs, while premium suspension continues;
* no evidence of the Life Insured’s health, occupation, income or pastimes, or any other Underwriting information is required following the suspension ending; and
* no Benefit will be payable in respect of any Sickness or Injury (whichever is applicable) that occurs while in suspension or during the 90 days following the suspension ending.

When you are ready to recommence cover you must first contact us to restart premium payments.

If no instruction is received from you or premiums are not restarted within 12 months from the start of the Superannuation Pause Benefit, the option to recommence cover will no longer be available and the Plan will be cancelled.

The Superannuation Pause Benefit does not apply where Superlink IP Standard has been selected.
ai_summary: The Superannuation Pause Benefit allows you to temporarily suspend premiums and coverage for up to 12 months if the Life Insured stops working for reasons other than Sickness or Injury, provided acceptable evidence is submitted. During this suspension, no premiums are due, no benefits are payable, and no health or underwriting information is required upon resuming coverage; however, no benefits will be paid for Sickness or Injury occurring during or within 90 days after the suspension. To restart coverage, you must contact the insurer, and if no action is taken within 12 months, the option to recommence will be lost, resulting in cancellation of the Plan. Note that this benefit is not available with Superlink IP Standard.

content:
If the Life Insured is a health care professional, for example a Medical Practitioner, surgeon or dentist, and they contract a blood borne disease such as HIV, Hepatitis B or C, their ability to work can be affected by factors other than physical inability due to the illness.

The following is our approach to claims.

There are three scenarios that could affect the Life Insured. For all three scenarios the Life Insured must notify the relevant governing body of their medical condition:
* the Life Insured chooses to disclose their condition to their patients which may lead to some of their patients seeking medical treatment elsewhere. It could also be difficult for the Life Insured to attract new patients; or
* the Life Insured chooses to cease performing Exposure Prone Procedures as defined by the relevant governing body; or
* the Life Insured’s governing body advises the Life Insured to cease performing Exposure Prone Procedures as defined by the relevant governing body.

With all of these scenarios it is likely that the Life Insured’s income will reduce.

In all of these cases we will assess whether the Life Insured is Totally Disabled or Partially Disabled in accordance with the terms and conditions of their Policy.

Where Income Protection Super has been selected (as indicated in the Policy Schedule), the Life Insured must also satisfy the SIS definition of Temporary Incapacity or Permanent Incapacity.
ai_summary: The Blood Borne Diseases Benefit under the Income Protection policy provides coverage for health care professionals, such as doctors and dentists, who contract blood borne diseases like HIV or Hepatitis B/C, potentially impacting their ability to work. Claim assessments will consider three scenarios affecting income: voluntary disclosure of their condition to patients, cessation of Exposure Prone Procedures, or advice from a governing body to cease such procedures. In all cases, the insured must notify the relevant governing body, and their income reduction will be evaluated to determine if they are Totally or Partially Disabled per policy terms. If Income Protection Super is selected, the insured must also meet the SIS definitions of Temporary or Permanent Incapacity.

content: The following additional benefits only apply if 'Premier' is shown in your Policy Schedule.
ai_summary: Section 7.2 outlines that the additional benefits under the 'Premier' designation in your Policy Schedule provide enhanced coverage options. These benefits are contingent upon the 'Premier' status being explicitly indicated in the Policy Schedule, ensuring that policyholders receive specialized income protection features.

content:
If Total Disability payments have accrued beyond the Waiting Period, the Child Care Benefit will reimburse the Life Insured for child care costs incurred solely because of the Sickness or Injury resulting in Total Disability.

If the Child Care Benefit applies, the amount paid in addition to the Total Disability Benefit will be the lesser of:
• five per cent of the Monthly Benefit;
• $500 per month; or
• the child care costs, less amounts reimbursed from elsewhere.

Each child must be under the age of 12 at the time when child care costs were incurred and evidence must be supplied each month that the child care costs to be reimbursed are from a licensed external child care provider.

The Child Care Benefit:
• is paid monthly in arrears; and
• will stop on the earlier of the following events:
– the Life Insured no longer being Totally Disabled;
– the end of the Benefit Period;
– the Policy anniversary before the Life Insured’s 65th birthday;
– the child no longer requires child care; or
– three months Child Care Benefit being paid for any one Total Disability.
ai_summary: The Child Care Benefit provides reimbursement for child care costs incurred due to Total Disability, payable monthly in arrears after the Waiting Period. The benefit amount is the lesser of 5% of the Monthly Benefit, $500, or actual child care costs (minus other reimbursements), applicable for children under 12 and requiring evidence from a licensed provider. Payments cease when the Life Insured is no longer Totally Disabled, at the end of the Benefit Period, on the policy anniversary before age 65, when child care is no longer needed, or after three months of payments for a single Total Disability.

content:
The Child’s Critical Illness Benefit is payable only if the child is financially dependent on the Life Insured and is aged (next birthday) between two and 19.

If the Life Insured’s child suffers a Critical Illness Event after the Plan or Policy start date, we will pay the Child’s Critical Illness Benefit.

The amount we pay under the Child’s Critical Illness Benefit is three times the Benefit Amount to a maximum of $25,000. The Child’s Critical Illness Benefit will only be paid:
• once per child under all Income Protection policies issued by us; and
• once under a Plan.

The Child’s Critical Illness Benefit is not payable on a Critical Illness Event which occurred or was diagnosed, or the signs or symptoms leading to diagnosis became apparent:
• where the child was aged less than two (next birthday); or
• before the Plan or Policy start date.

The Child’s Critical Illness Benefit ends on the Policy anniversary immediately before the Life Insured’s youngest child’s 19th birthday.
ai_summary: The Child's Critical Illness Benefit provides financial support if the Life Insured's child, aged between two and 19, suffers a Critical Illness Event after the policy start date, with a payout of three times the Benefit Amount, capped at $25,000. This benefit is payable only once per child across all policies and is not applicable for events diagnosed before the child turns two or prior to the policy's start date, ending on the policy anniversary before the child's 19th birthday.

content:
The Critical Illness conditions covered are:

| Heart conditions | Neurological conditions | Permanent conditions |
|---|---|---|
| • Cardiomyopathy (permanent) | • Coma (of specified severity) | • Blindness (permanent) |
| • Heart Attack ¹ | • Encephalitis and Meningitis (resulting in permanent neurological deficit) | • Loss of Hearing (permanent) |
| | • Major Head Trauma (with permanent neurological deficit) | • Loss of use of Limbs (permanent) |
| | • Meningococcal Disease (resulting in significant permanent impairment) | • Loss of Sight in One Eye and use of a Single Limb (permanent) |
| | • Paralysis (permanent) ² | • Loss of Speech (permanent) |
| | • Stroke (resulting in neurological deficit) ¹ | |
| | • Subacute Sclerosing Panencephalitis | |

| Organ Disorders | Cancer | Other events |
|---|---|---|
| • Chronic Kidney Failure (requiring transplantation or dialysis) | • Benign Brain Tumour (resulting in irreversible neurological deficit) | • Aplastic Anaemia (requiring treatment) |
| • Major Organ Transplant | • Cancer (excluding early stage cancers) ¹ | • Death |
| • Severe Burns (covering at least 20% of the body’s surface area) | | • Terminal Illness |
ai_summary: The Child's Critical Illness Benefit covers a range of severe health conditions, including specific heart conditions (e.g., heart attack, cardiomyopathy), neurological conditions (e.g., coma, stroke), permanent disabilities (e.g., blindness, loss of limbs), organ disorders (e.g., chronic kidney failure, major organ transplant), and certain cancers (excluding early-stage). Additionally, it includes coverage for significant events such as death and terminal illness, ensuring comprehensive financial protection for children diagnosed with these critical illnesses.

content:
1 In the case of these events, no benefit would be paid if the condition occurred or was diagnosed, or the signs or symptoms leading to diagnosis became apparent:
– within three months after the Plan’s start date;
– within three months after the date of an applied-for increase but only in respect of the increase; and
– within three months after the most recent date we agreed to reinstate either the Plan or Policy.
2 The Paralysis Support Benefit will not apply.
ai_summary: The Child's Critical Illness Benefit will not provide coverage for conditions diagnosed or showing symptoms within three months of the Plan's start date, any applied-for increase, or the most recent reinstatement date. Additionally, the Paralysis Support Benefit is excluded from this coverage.

content:
The Rehabilitation Benefit applies when the Life Insured has been Totally Disabled, is still Totally Disabled or Partially Disabled and, as a result, actively participates in a Rehabilitation Program that:
• is approved by us in writing before the Life Insured participates; and
• we agree will lead to reasonable opportunities for the Life Insured to work in a Gainful Occupation.
ai_summary: The Rehabilitation Benefit provides support for the Life Insured who is Totally or Partially Disabled and actively engages in a pre-approved Rehabilitation Program aimed at facilitating their return to Gainful Occupation. Approval must be obtained in writing from the insurer prior to participation, ensuring the program is aligned with reasonable employment opportunities for the insured.

The Rehabilitation Benefit provides an additional payment of 50% of the Benefit Amount alongside the Total Disability Benefit, commencing from the start of the Life Insured's active participation in a Rehabilitation Program and paid monthly in arrears. This benefit ceases upon the Life Insured no longer being Totally or Partially Disabled, reaching the end of the Benefit Period or Plan end date, discontinuing participation in the program, after 12 months of payments for a single claim, or if it is determined that the program will not yield reasonable re-employment opportunities.

The Return to Work Benefit begins accruing when the Life Insured engages in a Gainful Occupation of 30 hours or more per week and is paid in arrears. This benefit ceases upon the occurrence of any of the following: the end of the Benefit Period, the Plan end date, the Life Insured's reduction in work hours below 30 per week, or after three times the Benefit Amount has been disbursed for any Total or Partial Disability.

content:
If you spend money directly towards the effective rehabilitation of the Life Insured through a Rehabilitation Program, these funds will be reimbursed (less amounts reimbursed from elsewhere) subject to:
• our written approval of the expenditure being provided before it is incurred; and
• a maximum allowable reimbursement of six times the Benefit Amount.
The cost of medical consultations and medical therapy consultations, including but not limited to, physiotherapy, psychotherapy and hydrotherapy, will not be reimbursed.
ai_summary: The Rehabilitation Expense Reimbursement Benefit allows for reimbursement of expenses incurred for the effective rehabilitation of the Life Insured, subject to prior written approval and a maximum reimbursement limit of six times the Benefit Amount. However, costs related to medical consultations and therapies, such as physiotherapy, psychotherapy, and hydrotherapy, are not eligible for reimbursement.

content:
If the Life Insured is outside Australia and is Totally Disabled for 28 consecutive days and chooses to return to Australia while Totally Disabled, the Overseas Assistance Benefit will be paid.
The amount paid will be a reimbursement of the costs directly incurred by the Life Insured in returning to Australia, less amounts reimbursed from elsewhere, to a maximum of three times the Benefit Amount for any one claim. Airfare costs reimbursed will be in line with those that are medically necessary.
ai_summary: The Overseas Assistance Benefit provides reimbursement for costs incurred by a Life Insured who is Totally Disabled outside Australia and chooses to return home after 28 consecutive days of disability. The reimbursement, capped at three times the Benefit Amount per claim, covers medically necessary airfare and excludes any amounts reimbursed from other sources.

Subheading: Long Distance Accommodation and Transport Benefit
ai_summary: The Long Distance Accommodation and Transport Benefit provides reimbursement for accommodation costs, up to $250 per day, for an Immediate Family Member of the Life Insured if the Life Insured is Totally Disabled and Bed Confined more than 100 kilometres from their usual residence. This benefit begins accruing upon expenditure and is paid monthly in arrears, ceasing under specific conditions such as the Life Insured no longer being Bed Confined or after 30 days of payments for a single Total Disability. Additionally, transport costs incurred by the Life Insured are reimbursable up to $500 annually, excluding ambulance fees and other reimbursed amounts.

content:
The Return to Work Benefit will be paid when the Life Insured returns to a Gainful Occupation after having been in receipt of the Rehabilitation Benefit for at least three consecutive months.
If the Return to Work Benefit applies, the amount paid will be one times the Benefit Amount on each of the following:
• the Life Insured starting in a Gainful Occupation for 30 hours a week or more;
• the Life Insured continuing in that Gainful Occupation for three consecutive months for 30 hours a week or more; and
• the Life Insured continuing in that Gainful Occupation for six consecutive months for 30 hours a week or more.
ai_summary: The Return to Work Benefit is available to the Life Insured after receiving the Rehabilitation Benefit for at least three consecutive months, and it provides a payment equal to one times the Benefit Amount when the insured returns to a Gainful Occupation of 30 hours or more per week. Payments are issued upon starting the occupation, continuing for three consecutive months, and again for six consecutive months, each meeting the 30-hour weekly requirement.

content:
The Job Security Benefit will be paid if the Life Insured:
• does not directly or indirectly own all or part of the business in which the Own Occupation of the Life Insured is performed; and
• has been Totally Disabled for two consecutive months and subsequently returns to a Gainful Occupation with the same employer with whom the Life Insured was working before being Totally Disabled.
Payment will be made to the Life Insured’s employer and the amount paid will be one times the Benefit Amount for any one Total Disability.
• no evidence of the Life Insured’s health, occupation, income or pastimes, or any other Underwriting information, is required following the suspension ending; and
• no Benefit will be payable in respect of any Sickness or Injury (whichever is applicable) that occurs while in suspension or during the 90 days following the suspension ending.
When you are ready to recommence cover you must first contact us to restart premium payments.
If no instruction is received from you or premiums are not restarted within 12 months from the start of the Premium Pause Benefit, the option to recommence cover will no longer be available and the Plan will be cancelled.
ai_summary: The Job Security Benefit provides financial support to the Life Insured, paid to their employer, if they have been Totally Disabled for two consecutive months and return to a Gainful Occupation with the same employer, provided they do not own any part of the business. The benefit amount is equal to one times the Benefit Amount for the Total Disability, with no health or underwriting information required upon resuming coverage. However, no benefits are payable for any Sickness or Injury occurring during the suspension or within 90 days after it ends. To restart coverage after a Premium Pause, the Life Insured must contact the insurer; failure to do so within 12 months will result in cancellation of the Plan.

content:
This benefit only applies if you are both the Policy Owner and the Life Insured. The Involuntary Unemployment Benefit does not apply if you are self-employed or employed by a business of which you have control.
If the Life Insured becomes Involuntarily Unemployed for reasons other than Sickness or Injury, you may apply to have premiums waived for Income Protection (including all optional benefits) for up to three months in respect of an Unemployment event. During this period, your cover will remain active. The total accumulated period where we waive the premiums for Income Protection insurance under this benefit is 6 months.
We will only waive premiums in terms of this Involuntary Unemployment Benefit if:
• Income Protection Premier under this Policy has been in force for at least six months before the date of Involuntary Unemployment;
• you give us proof to our satisfaction of Involuntary Unemployment; and
• you are Unemployed at the time you applied to have your Income Protection premiums waived.
We will stop waiving the Income Protection premiums at the end of the three month period. If premiums are not paid after this period, your Policy will be cancelled.
ai_summary: The Involuntary Unemployment Benefit allows the Policy Owner and Life Insured to apply for a waiver of Income Protection premiums for up to three months if they become involuntarily unemployed, provided they have been insured for at least six months and can prove their unemployment status. This benefit does not apply to self-employed individuals or those controlling the business, and the total premium waiver period cannot exceed six months; failure to pay premiums after the waiver period will result in policy cancellation.

content:
You can apply to continue Income Protection insurance before the Policy anniversary before the Life Insured’s 65th birthday if the Life Insured:
• was aged 55 or less at the Plan start date;
• has a ‘to age 65’ Benefit Period; and
• has been continuously working in a Gainful Occupation for 12 months immediately before the Plan end date and can provide occupational and financial evidence acceptable to us that the Life Insured will continue to work in a Gainful Occupation.
This is subject to:
• an application in writing being received by us within 30 days of the Policy anniversary before the Life Insured’s 65th birthday;
• the Benefit Period will become one year;
• the Waiting Period will be the greater of the existing Waiting Period and four weeks;
• the Benefit Amount will be the lesser of the existing Benefit Amount and $10,000; and
• your premium will increase to take into account the change of Benefit Period according to the current premium rates, and with regard to the Life Insured’s age, at the time of application for increase in Benefit Period.
The Cover Continuation Benefit is not available if:
• the Life Insured is Totally Disabled or Partially Disabled at the time of cover expiry date (either during the Waiting Period or while a benefit is payable); or
• the Life Insured has a medical loading or medical exclusion showing on the Policy Schedule.
When Superlink IP is selected, cover can be continued only on the non-superannuation policy.
ai_summary: The Cover Continuation Benefit allows the Life Insured to extend their Income Protection insurance until age 65, provided they are 55 or younger at the Plan start date, have a 'to age 65' Benefit Period, and have worked continuously in a Gainful Occupation for the 12 months prior to the Plan end date. To apply, a written request must be submitted within 30 days of the Policy anniversary before the Life Insured turns 65, with the new Benefit Period limited to one year, a potential increase in premium, and a maximum Benefit Amount of $10,000. This benefit is unavailable if the Life Insured is Totally or Partially Disabled at the expiry date or has medical exclusions noted in the Policy Schedule.

The Premium Pause Benefit allows policyholders to temporarily suspend premium payments and the associated plan for up to 12 months after 12 consecutive months of premium payments, provided the Life Insured has stopped working due to Unemployment or Long Term Leave. During this suspension, no premiums are due, no Benefit Amount is payable, and no indexation occurs, contingent upon the submission of acceptable evidence of the Life Insured's work cessation.

The Guaranteed Future Insurability Benefit allows policyholders to increase their Benefit Amount by up to 15% every two years, contingent upon a written application within 30 days of the policy's second anniversary and submission of acceptable financial evidence of the Life Insured's earnings. This benefit is subject to several conditions, including the prohibition of applications if a claim has been made within six months, a cap on the total Benefit Amount, and an end to the benefit before the Life Insured's 55th birthday. Additionally, any increase in the Benefit Amount will result in a premium adjustment, and the benefit is not applicable if exclusions or increased premiums due to medical history were applied at the policy's inception.

The Waiting Period for Income Protection can be shortened if the Life Insured changes employment, provided certain conditions are met, including an increase in premium based on age and new rates, written proof of employment change, and a request within 30 days. The Life Insured must not be Totally or Partially Disabled at the time, must not be eligible for income protection through the new employer, and must have prior coverage under an employer-related policy with a Benefit Period of one year or more. Additionally, any existing medical loadings or exclusions in the Policy Schedule will disqualify the Life Insured from this benefit.

content:
Existing Waiting Period | Shortened Waiting Period
---|---
104 weeks or 52 weeks | 13 weeks or 26 weeks
26 weeks | 13 weeks
13 weeks | 4 weeks or 8 weeks
ai_summary: The table outlines the options for changing the waiting period benefit in an income protection policy, allowing policyholders to reduce their waiting periods from existing terms of 104 or 26 weeks to shorter durations of 13, 4, or 8 weeks, depending on the original waiting period selected. This flexibility can enhance immediate financial support during periods of income loss.

content:
We consider that employment status has changed where:

* the Life Insured has ceased work for one employer and has commenced employment with another employer not related to the first employer and of which the Life Insured has no ownership interest in the business; or
* the Life Insured ceases being self-employed (ie shareholder or employee of own company, sole trader or partner) and commences employment with a new employer of which the Life Insured has no ownership interest in the business.
ai_summary: The Change of Waiting Period Benefit under the Income Protection policy recognizes a change in employment status when the Life Insured transitions from one unrelated employer to another, or shifts from self-employment to a new employer, provided they have no ownership interest in the new business. This provision ensures that the Life Insured's coverage remains valid during significant employment changes.

content: Benefit Options listed below only apply if indicated in your Policy Schedule.
ai_summary: Section 7.3 outlines that the optional benefit options for Income Protection are only applicable if they are explicitly stated in your Policy Schedule. It is essential for policyholders to review their schedule to understand which additional benefits they may be entitled to under their coverage.

content:
If a Total Disability Benefit, Partial Disability Benefit or the Scheduled Injury Benefit is payable and the Increasing Claim Option is included, the Benefit Amount will increase on the anniversary of the commencement of the benefit payments by the Indexation Factor. This increase will be limited to five per cent when Income Protection is structured through superannuation.
The Increasing Claim Option is available under:
• Income Protection ‘Super’, ‘Standard’ and ‘Premier’; and
• if applicable, the Retirement Protection Option.
Where Income Protection Super has been selected (as indicated in the Policy Schedule), the benefit payable must not exceed the Pre-Disability Earnings.
ai_summary: The Increasing Claim Option allows for the Benefit Amount of Total Disability, Partial Disability, or Scheduled Injury Benefits to increase annually by the Indexation Factor, capped at five percent when structured through superannuation. This option is available for Income Protection policies labeled ‘Super’, ‘Standard’, and ‘Premier’, as well as the Retirement Protection Option, but any benefits under Income Protection Super cannot exceed Pre-Disability Earnings as specified in the Policy Schedule.

The Retirement Protection Option, available through Income Protection Standard or Premier, reimburses superannuation contributions made by or on behalf of the Life Insured during periods of Total or Partial Disability. If 'Agreed Value' is selected, reimbursement is capped at the stated Benefit Amount; if 'Indemnity' is chosen, it is limited to the lesser of the Benefit Amount, average contributions over the past year, or 10% of Pre-Disability Earnings. Payments commence after the Waiting Period, are made monthly in arrears, and cease when the Life Insured is no longer disabled, the Benefit Period ends, or they reach age 65.

content:
If the Life Insured is Totally Disabled as a result of an Accident for 72 consecutive hours immediately following an Accident during the Waiting Period, 1/30th of the Benefit Amount will be paid for each day the Life Insured is Totally Disabled.
Payment will stop on the earlier of:
• the Life Insured no longer being Totally Disabled;
• the Plan end date; or
• the expiry of 14 days if your Policy has a 2 week Waiting Period, and 28 days if your Policy has a Waiting Period of longer than 2 weeks.
When the Life Insured is eligible for payment under the Scheduled Injury Benefit, Bed Confinement Benefit, Critical Illness Option and Accident Benefit Option, only the greater of these benefit payments will be paid.
ai_summary: The Accident Benefit Option provides that if the Life Insured is Totally Disabled due to an Accident for 72 consecutive hours during the Waiting Period, they will receive 1/30th of the Benefit Amount for each day of Total Disability. Payments cease when the Life Insured is no longer Totally Disabled, at the Plan end date, or after 14 or 28 days depending on the Waiting Period. Additionally, if the Life Insured qualifies for multiple benefits, only the highest payment will be issued.

content:
Only available through Income Protection Standard or Premier.
If the Life Insured suffers a Critical Illness Event listed below, we will pay the Critical Illness Option.
The amount paid under the Critical Illness Option is six times the Benefit Amount. The Critical Illness Option is paid as a lump sum in addition to any Total Disability or Partial Disability entitlements.
We will only pay a benefit for one Critical Illness Event occurring in any six-month period under the Critical Illness Option. This period will be deemed to have commenced on the date of the first Critical Illness Event.
At the end of six months, eligibility for other benefits will be based on appropriate Plan conditions being satisfied.
These Critical Illness Events are defined in Section 10.3 of this Policy Document.
We will only pay once for each Critical Illness Event condition under the Critical Illness Option for the life of the Policy.
When the Life Insured is eligible for payment under the Scheduled Injury Benefit, Accident Benefit Option and Critical Illness Option, only the greater of these benefit payments will be paid.
The Critical Illness Option is only available for Waiting Periods up to and including 13 weeks.
ai_summary: The Critical Illness Option, available only through Income Protection Standard or Premier, pays a lump sum of six times the Benefit Amount if the Life Insured suffers a specified Critical Illness Event. Benefits are limited to one payment per six-month period for each event, and eligibility for additional benefits resumes after this period, subject to plan conditions. The option is applicable only for Waiting Periods of up to 13 weeks, and if multiple benefits are available, only the highest payment will be issued. Detailed definitions of Critical Illness Events can be found in Section 10.3 of the Policy Document.

content:
Heart conditions
* Angioplasty 1,3
* Aortic Surgery
* Cardiomyopathy (permanent)
* Heart Attack 1
* Heart Valve Surgery 1
* Coronary Artery Bypass Surgery 1
* Open Heart Surgery 1
* Out of Hospital Cardiac Arrest 1
* Primary Pulmonary Hypertension
* Triple Vessel Angioplasty 1
Neurological conditions
* Coma (of specified severity)
* Dementia including Alzheimer’s Disease (permanent)
* Encephalitis and Meningitis (resulting in permanent neurological deficit)
* Major Head Trauma (with permanent neurological deficit)
* Meningococcal Disease (resulting in significant permanent impairment)
* Multiple Sclerosis (with multiple episodes of neurological deficit and persisting neurological abnormalities) 1
* Muscular Dystrophy
* Paralysis (permanent)
* Parkinson’s Disease (permanent)
* Progressive and Debilitating Motor Neurone Disease
* Stroke (resulting in neurological deficit) 1
Permanent conditions
* Blindness (permanent)
* Loss of Hearing (permanent)
* Loss of Independent Existence (permanent)
* Loss of use of a Single Limb (permanent)
* Loss of Speech (permanent)
Organ disorders
* Chronic Kidney Failure (requiring transplantation or dialysis)
* Chronic Liver Failure (resulting in permanent symptoms)
* Chronic Lung Failure (requiring permanent oxygen therapy)
* Major Organ Transplant
* Pneumonectomy
* Severe Burns (covering at least 20% of the body’s surface area)
Blood disorders
* Aplastic Anaemia (requiring treatment)
* Medically-Acquired HIV (contracted from a medical procedure or operation)
* Occupationally-Acquired HIV
* Occupationally-Acquired Hepatitis B or C 2
Cancer
* Benign Brain Tumour (resulting in irreversible neurological deficit)
* Cancer (excluding early stage cancers) 1
Other events
* Intensive Care (requiring 5 days of continuous intubation) 3
ai_summary: Section 7 of the insurance document outlines critical illness events covered under income protection, categorized into heart conditions (e.g., heart attack, open heart surgery), neurological conditions (e.g., stroke, paralysis), permanent conditions (e.g., permanent blindness, loss of speech), organ disorders (e.g., chronic kidney failure, major organ transplant), blood disorders (e.g., medically-acquired HIV), cancer (e.g., advanced cancer excluding early stages), and other events (e.g., intensive care requiring prolonged intubation). Each condition has specific criteria for coverage, emphasizing the importance of permanent or severe impairments for claims eligibility.

content:
1 In the case of these events, no benefit will be paid if the condition occurred or was diagnosed, or the signs or symptoms leading to diagnosis became apparent, to a reasonable person in the position of the Life Insured:
* within three months after the Plan start date;
* within three months after the date of an applied-for increase but only in respect of the increase; and
* within three months after the most recent date that we have agreed to reinstate either the Plan or Policy.
No benefit is payable for any other Critical Illness event that arises directly or indirectly as a result of an event excluded in this section.
2 Only applicable when your occupation class is AA+ as indicated in your Policy schedule. A benefit is only payable for these conditions under the Needlestick Benefit.
3 The amount to be paid is the lesser of six times the Benefit Amount and $50,000.
ai_summary: Section 7 of the Income Protection policy outlines that no benefits will be paid for conditions diagnosed or showing symptoms within three months of the plan's start date, any applied increase, or reinstatement of the policy. Additionally, benefits are only available for specific conditions under the Needlestick Benefit for those in occupation class AA+, with the payout capped at the lesser of six times the Benefit Amount or $50,000. No benefits will be provided for Critical Illness events linked to excluded conditions.

content:
If the occupation class of the Life Insured is AA+ as specified in the Policy Schedule, the Needlestick Benefit will be payable under the Critical Illness Option when the Life Insured suffers Occupationally-Acquired HIV or Occupationally-Acquired Hepatitis B or C.
We will increase the amount we will pay under the Critical Illness Option to fifty times the Benefit Amount to a maximum of $1 million, and the Critical Illness Option will end.
If you choose the Critical Illness Option under Income Protection in conjunction with Critical Illness Premier, you will be limited to a maximum benefit of $1 million across all policies issued by TAL in the event of Occupationally-Acquired Hepatitis B or C.
In the event of cover being held simultaneously through the Critical Illness Option under Income Protection and Critical Illness Premier, the Needlestick Benefit for Occupationally-Acquired Hepatitis B or C will be paid through the Income Protection plan first.
ai_summary: The Needlestick Benefit under the Income Protection policy is available for Life Insured individuals in occupation class AA+ who contract Occupationally-Acquired HIV or Hepatitis B or C, providing a payout of up to fifty times the Benefit Amount, capped at $1 million. If the Critical Illness Option is selected alongside Critical Illness Premier, the total benefit across all TAL policies for Hepatitis B or C is limited to $1 million, with the Income Protection plan paying out first in cases of simultaneous coverage.

content:
Only available through Income Protection Standard or Premier.
If the Life Insured is Totally Disabled or Partially Disabled and his or her business suffers an Operating Loss solely because of a Sickness or Injury, the Business Expense Benefit will be paid when:
• the Life Insured has been either Totally Disabled or Partially Disabled for the Waiting Period; and
• at the end of the Waiting Period the Life Insured remains Totally Disabled or Partially Disabled.
ai_summary: The Business Expense Option, available only through Income Protection Standard or Premier, provides benefits if the Life Insured experiences an Operating Loss due to Sickness or Injury while Totally or Partially Disabled. To qualify for the Business Expense Benefit, the Life Insured must have been disabled for the specified Waiting Period and must continue to be disabled at the end of this period.

content:
The Business Expense Benefit payable will be the lesser of:
• the Business Expense Benefit; and
• Life Insured’s share of the Operating Loss incurred.
An Operating Loss is Life Insured’s share of the Business Income less Business Expenses.
Business Expenses are expenses which are reasonable and necessarily incurred in generating Business Income, excluding salaries, fees, moneys or benefits paid to the Life Insured, depreciation, stock or items of a capital nature. Business Expenses relating to a period longer than one month will be pro-rated.
Business Income means the Life Insured’s share of the business turnover less the costs of goods sold (if applicable). If there is a delay between the time the Life Insured generated the Business Income and when the Life Insured actually received it, we will deem the Business Income to have been received in the month in which it was actually generated.
Other payments received by the Life Insured through any other business expense insurance will be considered as Business Income.
ai_summary: The Business Expense Benefit will be the lesser of the designated benefit amount or the Life Insured's share of the Operating Loss, calculated as Business Income minus Business Expenses. Business Expenses must be reasonable and necessary for generating income, excluding personal payments, depreciation, and capital items, with expenses over one month pro-rated. Business Income is defined as the Life Insured's share of turnover minus the cost of goods sold, recognized in the month generated, and any other business expense insurance payments will count as Business Income.

content:
A benefit under the Business Expense Option:
• starts to accrue after the Waiting Period ends;
• is paid monthly in arrears; and
• will stop on the earlier of the following events:
– cancellation or expiry of the Income Protection Plan under which the Business Expense Option applies;
– the Life Insured no longer being Totally Disabled or Partially Disabled;
– the end of the Benefit Period or Payment Extension Benefit (where applicable); or
– the Policy Anniversary before the Life Insured’s 65th birthday.
The Business Expense Benefit can be payable without requiring immediate financial evidence of Operating Losses incurred during the first three months after the Waiting Period.
After the first three months, Business Expense Benefit payments will be payable subject to our receipt of evidence satisfactory to us for the first three months and any ongoing period. If upon our review, the Business Expense Benefit paid in the first three months exceeds the Business Expense Benefit payable under the terms and conditions of the Business Expense Option, we will reconcile any payments made.
If the Life Insured has any other policy with us for which we have been provided with any financial information in relation to another claim, we will use that financial information to determine the actual Operating Loss incurred for the relevant period.
ai_summary: The Business Expense Option provides a monthly benefit that begins after the Waiting Period and ceases upon certain events, such as the cancellation of the Income Protection Plan or the Life Insured no longer being Totally or Partially Disabled. Benefits are payable without immediate financial evidence for the first three months, but thereafter require satisfactory evidence of Operating Losses. If initial payments exceed the allowable benefit, a reconciliation will occur. Additionally, financial information from other policies may be utilized to assess Operating Losses for claims under this option.

The Payment Extension Benefit allows for an extension of the Benefit Period for the Business Expense Option if the Life Insured remains Totally or Partially Disabled and has received less than 12 times the Business Expense Benefit by the end of the initial period. This extension lasts for up to 12 months or until one of several conditions occurs: the Life Insured recovers, the plan expires or is canceled, or the total benefits paid reach 12 times the Business Expense Benefit.

content:
Superlink IP allows Income Protection Standard and Income Protection Premier to be Superlinked to an Income Protection Super Policy.

If you select the Superlink option, two policies will be issued. An Income Protection Super Policy will be issued to the trustee of a superannuation fund, and an Income Protection Standard Policy or Income Protection Premier Policy will be issued to the Life Insured and Superlinked to the Income Protection Super Policy. Your Policy Schedules will indicate where Superlink applies for Income Protection.
ai_summary: Superlink IP enables the combination of Income Protection Standard and Income Protection Premier policies with an Income Protection Super Policy, facilitating coverage through a superannuation fund. By choosing the Superlink option, two separate policies are issued: one to the trustee of the super fund and the other to the Life Insured, ensuring that the Income Protection coverage is effectively linked to the superannuation policy, as indicated in the Policy Schedules.

The Payment Extension Benefit for the Income Protection policies stipulates that the Benefit Amount, Type of Cover, Waiting Period, and Benefit Period must align across both policies. Any adjustments to Income Protection under one policy will concurrently affect the other. If the Income Protection Super Policy is canceled, the non-superannuation Policy will also be canceled unless written notice is provided to retain it. Conversely, if the non-superannuation Policy is canceled, coverage will persist under the Income Protection Super Policy, with Superlink IP ceasing to apply. Additionally, the total benefits from both policies cannot exceed the maximum payable under a single Income Protection Standard or Premier Policy.

content: Claims will first be assessed with reference to the terms and conditions under the Income Protection Super Policy, and any amount payable will be paid to the trustee of the superannuation fund on your behalf. Any benefits not payable under the Income Protection Super Policy may be paid under the non-superannuation Policy, subject to the Life Insured meeting the applicable terms and conditions.
ai_summary: The Payment Extension Benefit under the Income Protection Super Policy stipulates that claims are evaluated based on the policy's terms and conditions, with any approved amounts disbursed to the superannuation fund trustee. Additionally, if benefits are not covered by the Income Protection Super Policy, they may still be available under a non-superannuation policy, provided the Life Insured fulfills the relevant terms and conditions.

content: Where the Life Insured suffers a Scheduled Injury, a benefit will be paid under the Scheduled Injury Benefit. Any subsequent benefit entitlement after the Payment Period for the Scheduled Injury Benefit will then be assessed in the manner as described in the paragraph above.
ai_summary: The Payment Extension Benefit provides that if the Life Insured experiences a Scheduled Injury, they will receive a benefit under the Scheduled Injury Benefit. Following the Payment Period for this benefit, any additional entitlement will be evaluated according to the previously outlined criteria.

content: Your Policy Schedules will indicate when Superlink IP applies.
ai_summary: The Payment Extension Benefit under the Income Protection section of your policy provides coverage details specific to Superlink IP, as indicated in your Policy Schedules. This benefit may extend payments under certain conditions, ensuring continued financial support during periods of income loss, subject to the terms outlined in the policy.

content: These are the standard limitations and exclusions that apply to the Policy. We are also not liable to pay a claim arising from, or in any way connected with, anything we have specifically excluded or adjusted in your Policy Schedule or is specified in any other part of this Policy.
ai_summary: Section 8 outlines the standard limitations and exclusions of the Policy, stating that the insurer is not liable for claims related to any items specifically excluded or adjusted in the Policy Schedule or detailed elsewhere in the Policy. This emphasizes the importance of reviewing these exclusions to understand the coverage limitations.

content:
Exclusions
No payments will be made under Life insurance, and any included or optional benefits (if applicable), if the claim arises directly or indirectly as a result of an intentional, self-inflicted act by the Life Insured:
• within 13 months after the Plan start date;
• within 13 months after the date of an applied for increase but only in respect of the increase amount; and
• within 13 months after the most recent date we agreed to reinstate either the Plan or Policy.
ai_summary: Life insurance claims will not be paid if they result from intentional, self-inflicted acts by the insured within specific timeframes: 13 months from the plan start date, 13 months following any increase in coverage, or 13 months after the reinstatement of the plan or policy. This exclusion applies to both included and optional benefits.

content:
We will waive the above exclusion if, immediately before the commencement of cover, you had death cover on the Life Insured that was in force for at least 13 consecutive months (without the death cover being cancelled and/ or reinstated) with TAL or another insurer, and you have replaced the death cover with Life insurance under this Policy. The waiver will only apply up to the level of cover you had with TAL or the other insurer.
Should you reinstate your death cover, this exclusion will recommence from the date of reinstatement.
