If the Life insurance Benefit Amount is reinstated or purchased as a result of using the Double TPD or Double Critical Illness Option or repurchased using the Death Buy-Back Option on TPD insurance or the Death Buy-Back Benefit on Critical Illness insurance, or any similar option, the Inflation Protection Benefit, Guaranteed Future Insurability Benefit and Business Insurance Option do not apply.
Any cover bought back under the Death Buy-Back Option or Benefit (or benefit of a similar type or intent) will be issued subject to the limitations and conditions, exclusions and loadings which were applicable to the original Policy. Cover will also not extend to benefits (or benefits of a similar type or intent) which were not covered under the original Policy.
ai_summary: This section outlines that the exclusion for life insurance will be waived if the insured had continuous death cover for at least 13 months prior to the new policy, provided it is replaced with this Life insurance policy. The waiver is limited to the previous coverage amount and will restart if the death cover is reinstated. Additionally, benefits like Inflation Protection and Guaranteed Future Insurability do not apply to reinstated or repurchased coverage through certain options, and any buy-back coverage will adhere to the original policy's limitations and exclusions.

content:
Adjustments
Where the Policy Schedule indicates TPD insurance is Attached or Linked to Life insurance then payments under TPD insurance will reduce the Life insurance Benefit Amount by the amount paid.
Where the Policy Schedule indicates Critical Illness insurance is Attached or Linked to Life insurance then payments under Critical Illness insurance will reduce the Life insurance Benefit Amount by the amount paid.
ai_summary: In cases where Total Permanent Disability (TPD) or Critical Illness insurance is linked to Life insurance, any payments made under TPD or Critical Illness will reduce the Life insurance Benefit Amount by the corresponding payment amount.

Life insurance coverage under this Plan terminates upon the earliest of the following events: receipt of a written cancellation request from the Policy Owner, cancellation due to non-payment of premiums, the policy anniversary before the Life Insured turns 100, cancellation due to non-disclosure or misrepresentation, the death of the Life Insured, or when the full Benefit Amount is paid or reduced to zero. Notably, the Financial Planning Benefit and Grief Counselling Benefit remain available for 12 months after the Benefit Amount is disbursed.

Life insurance coverage under TAL Super will terminate upon the earliest occurrence of several events: receipt of a written cancellation request, policy cancellation due to non-payment, reaching the policy anniversary before the Life Insured's 75th birthday (with an option to transfer ownership until age 100), cancellation due to non-disclosure or fraudulent claims, the death of the Life Insured, or when the full Benefit Amount is paid or reduced to nil.

content:
Exclusions
No payments will be made under Critical Illness insurance and any included or optional benefits (if applicable):
• if the claim arises directly or indirectly as a result of an intentional, self-inflicted act by the Life Insured; or
• if a claim arises directly or indirectly as a result of:
– Angioplasty
– Coronary Artery Bypass Surgery
– Cancer (excluding early stage cancers)
– Heart Attack
– Heart Valve Surgery
– Multiple Sclerosis (with episodes of neurological deficit and persisting neurological abnormalities)
– Open Heart Surgery
– Out of Hospital Cardiac Arrest
– Triple Vessel Angioplasty
– Stroke (resulting in neurological deficit)
– Carcinoma In Situ
– Diagnosed Benign Brain Tumour
– Early Stage Chronic Lymphocytic Leukaemia
– Early Stage Melanoma (excluding Melanoma In Situ)
– Adult onset insulin dependent diabetes mellitus diagnosed after age 30
– Early Stage Prostate Cancer;
if the condition occurred or was diagnosed, or the signs or symptoms leading to diagnosis became apparent to the Life Insured or would have become apparent to a reasonable person in the position of the Life Insured:
– within three months after the Plan start date;
– within three months after the date of an applied-for increase but only in respect of the increase; and
– within three months after the most recent date we agreed to reinstate either the Plan or Policy.
We will waive this three-month period if:
• you were insured with us or another insurer for the same events immediately before your cover starts; and
• you transferred your cover after any similar three month period.
The waiver will only apply up to the level of critical illness cover that you had with us or the other insurer. Should you reinstate your cover, the three-month period will recommence from the date of reinstatement.
Unless Attached or Linked to Life insurance, no payment will be made under Critical Illness insurance unless the Life Insured survives a Critical Illness Event for at least 14 days.
ai_summary: Critical Illness insurance will not provide payments for claims resulting from intentional self-harm or specific medical conditions, including various heart surgeries, cancer (excluding early stages), and certain neurological disorders, if these conditions were diagnosed or symptoms appeared within three months of the plan's start date, an increase, or reinstatement. A waiver of this three-month limitation applies if the insured had prior coverage for the same events. Additionally, benefits are contingent on the Life Insured surviving a Critical Illness Event for at least 14 days, unless the policy is linked to Life insurance.

content:
Under the Child’s Critical Illness Benefit no payments will be made for:
• Cancer (excluding early stage cancers)
• Heart Attack
• Stroke (resulting in neurological deficit);
if that event occurred or was diagnosed, or the signs or symptoms leading to diagnosis became apparent:
• within three months after the Plan start date; and
• within three months after the most recent date we agreed to reinstate either the Plan or Policy.
No payment will be made under the Child’s Critical Illness Benefit if the Critical Illness Event is caused directly or indirectly by the intentional act of a person who stands to derive a benefit from the claim payment.
Any cover bought back under the Critical Illness Reinstatement Option (or benefit of a similar type or intent) will be issued subject to the limitations and conditions, exclusions and loadings which were applicable to the original policy. Cover will also not extend to critical illness events (or events of a similar type or intent) which were not covered under the original policy.
ai_summary: The Child’s Critical Illness Benefit excludes payments for specific conditions such as cancer (excluding early-stage), heart attack, and stroke if diagnosed or symptomatic within three months of the plan's start date or recent reinstatement. Additionally, no benefits will be paid if the critical illness is caused by an intentional act of someone benefiting from the claim. Any reinstated coverage will adhere to the original policy's limitations, exclusions, and conditions, and will not cover illnesses not included in the original policy.

The Benefit Amount for the insurance policy will be reduced by payments made for specific benefits including Advancement Benefit, Angioplasty, Intensive Care (after 5 days of intubation), Paralysis Support Benefit, Needlestick Benefit, and Female Critical Illness Benefit. Additionally, if Critical Illness insurance is linked to Life insurance, it will be canceled upon payment of the Death Benefit or Terminal Illness Benefit. Furthermore, any payments made under Total Permanent Disability (TPD) insurance linked to Critical Illness will also reduce the Critical Illness Benefit Amount accordingly.

Critical Illness insurance terminates under several conditions, including cancellation requests, non-payment of premiums, or upon the Life Insured's death. Coverage also ends at specific policy anniversaries—before the Life Insured's 70th birthday or the Insured Child's 19th birthday—unless linked to Life insurance, in which case it may extend until the Life Insured's 100th birthday if the Life insurance remains active. If the Life insurance lapses or is canceled, the Critical Illness insurance may continue under certain conditions, but premium rates will increase, and the Death Buy-Back Benefit will cease.

content:
Exclusions
Under the Child’s Critical Illness Insurance no payments will be made for:
* Cancer (excluding early stage cancers)
* Heart Attack
* Stroke (resulting in neurological deficit);
if that event occurred or was diagnosed, or the signs or symptoms leading to diagnosis became apparent:
* within three months after the Child’s Critical Illness Insurance or the Child’s Critical Illness Benefit start date; and
* within three months after the most recent date we agreed to reinstate either the Plan or Policy.
No payment will be made under the Child’s Critical Illness Insurance if the Critical Illness Event arises directly or indirectly as a result of an intentional act of a person who stands to derive a benefit from the claim payment.
ai_summary: The Child's Critical Illness Insurance excludes payments for certain conditions, including cancer (except early stage), heart attack, and stroke, if these events occur or are diagnosed within three months of the insurance start date or any reinstatement date. Additionally, no payments will be made if the critical illness arises from an intentional act by someone who benefits from the claim.

Subheading: When Child’s Critical Illness insurance ends
ai_summary: Child’s Critical Illness insurance coverage terminates upon the earliest of the following events: receipt of a written cancellation request, policy cancellation due to non-payment, the policy anniversary prior to the insured child's 19th birthday, cancellation due to non-disclosure or fraudulent claims, the death of the insured child, or upon full payment of the Benefit Amount, after which certain benefits remain available for 12 months.

content:
No payment will be made under TPD insurance and any included or optional Benefits (if applicable) if the claim arises directly or indirectly as a result of an intentional, self-inflicted act by the Life Insured.
Unless Attached or Linked to Life insurance, no payment will be made under TPD insurance unless the Life Insured survives the Sickness or Injury which resulted in Total and Permanent Disability for at least 14 days.
Where TPD insurance is Attached or Linked to Life insurance or Attached to Critical Illness insurance, then the following provisions will also apply:
• if the Life insurance or Critical Illness insurance is in force on the Policy anniversary before the Life Insured’s 65th birthday, then:
– the TPD insurance will continue;
– Loss of Independent Existence (permanent), Loss of use of Limbs (permanent) and Blindness (permanent) will become the only definitions that apply to future claims under the TPD insurance where an ‘Any Occupation’ or ‘Own Occupation’ definition is shown in the Policy Schedule; and
– the TPD insurance Benefit Amount will be restricted to a maximum of $1,000,000;
ai_summary: Under TPD insurance, no benefits will be paid for claims resulting from intentional self-inflicted acts, and the insured must survive the qualifying sickness or injury for at least 14 days. If TPD insurance is linked to Life or Critical Illness insurance and remains active before the insured's 65th birthday, it will continue, with future claims limited to specific conditions (Loss of Independent Existence, permanent loss of limbs, or permanent blindness) and a maximum benefit amount of $1,000,000.

content:
Where TPD insurance is Attached or Linked to Life insurance, the TPD insurance will be cancelled if the Death Benefit or Terminal Illness Benefit is paid.
Where TPD insurance is Attached to Critical Illness insurance and/or Life insurance, the Benefit Amount for TPD insurance and/or Life insurance (if applicable) will be reduced by any Critical Illness insurance paid.
If Superlink TPD Insurance is reduced or increased under one Policy, Superlink TPD Insurance on the other Policy will be reduced or increased (as applicable) at the same time. If TPD is cancelled under the superannuation Policy, the non-superannuation Policy will also be cancelled unless you apply to retain the Plan outside of superannuation before cancellation.
If TPD is cancelled under the non-superannuation Policy, cover will continue under the superannuation Policy, and Superlink TPD will no longer apply.
ai_summary: In cases where Total Permanent Disability (TPD) insurance is linked to Life insurance, the TPD coverage will be canceled upon payment of the Death or Terminal Illness Benefit. If TPD insurance is connected to Critical Illness insurance, any benefits paid will reduce the TPD and/or Life insurance Benefit Amount accordingly. Adjustments to Superlink TPD Insurance under one policy will simultaneously affect the other policy. Cancellation of TPD under a superannuation policy will also cancel the non-superannuation policy unless a retention application is submitted prior to cancellation. Conversely, if TPD is canceled under the non-superannuation policy, coverage will persist under the superannuation policy, and Superlink TPD will cease to apply.

TPD insurance coverage ends upon the earliest of several conditions, including the Policy Owner's written cancellation request, non-payment of premiums, or specific policy anniversaries related to the Life Insured's age (65, 70, or 100 years). Coverage may also terminate due to fraudulent non-disclosure, the Life Insured's death, or full benefit payment. If the TPD insurance is linked to Life or Critical Illness insurance, it may continue under certain conditions, but will be subject to premium increases and limitations on the benefit amount. If the linked insurance lapses or is cancelled, TPD coverage will cease accordingly.

Subheading: 8.5 Income Protection Super, Standard and Premier
ai_summary: Payments under the Income Protection policy, including optional benefits, will not be made for claims resulting from intentional self-harm, normal pregnancy-related conditions, war-related incidents, or any restrictions on the Life Insured's ability to perform their occupation. Additionally, for the Critical Illness Option, the Life Insured must survive a Critical Illness Event for a minimum of 14 days to qualify for payment.

content:
Adjustments only apply to payments under the Total Disability Benefit, the Partial Disability Benefit and the Scheduled Injury Benefit.
Where Income Protection is structured outside of superannuation, a reduction will only be made if the Life Insured received other payment(s) through:
• any other individual or group disability income insurance, credit or mortgage insurance not disclosed at the time of underwriting, increase in benefits or reinstatement of the Policy; or
• workers’ compensation, common law or statute where payments are in respect of the disability of the Life Insured and in calculation the payment the relevant authority did not, or could not, take into account payments due under the Plan (not applicable if the occupation class of the Life Insured is AAA or AA+).
Where Income Protection is structured through superannuation, a reduction will only be made if you receive other payment(s) through:
• any other individual or group disability income insurance, credit or mortgage insurance;
• workers’ compensation, common law or statute where payments are in respect of your disability and in calculation the payment the relevant authority did not, or could not, take into account payments due under the Plan; or
• sick leave, where you have accrued entitlements at the commencement of the Waiting Period and choose to use those entitlements during the Benefit Period (only applicable when Income Protection is structured through superannuation).
ai_summary: Adjustments to payments under the Total Disability Benefit, Partial Disability Benefit, and Scheduled Injury Benefit apply based on other income received by the Life Insured. For Income Protection outside superannuation, reductions occur if the insured receives undisclosed payments from other disability insurances or workers' compensation, unless classified as AAA or AA+. For superannuation-structured Income Protection, reductions apply if the insured receives payments from any other disability insurance, workers' compensation, or utilizes accrued sick leave during the Benefit Period.

content:
If any of the other payments above is received as a lump sum, it will be converted to a monthly amount on the basis of 1% of the lump sum for each month that a disability benefit is paid. The disability payment will be calculated taking this figure into account for a maximum of eight years.
If an adjustment applies it will be to ensure that the benefit payable plus the other payments including Earnings is not greater than the following:
Total Disability:
– 75% of the first $26,666 ($320,000 pa) of Pre-Disability Earnings;
– 50% of the next $20,000 ($240,000 pa) of Pre-Disability Earnings; and
– 20% of Pre-Disability Earnings above $46,666 ($560,000 pa).
The amount of the reduction will not exceed the amount of the other payments.
Partial Disability:
– 100% of Pre-Disability Earnings.
ai_summary: TPD insurance benefits may be adjusted if lump sum payments are received, converting them to a monthly amount based on 1% of the lump sum for each month disability benefits are paid, with a maximum duration of eight years. Total Disability benefits are capped at 75% of the first $26,666, 50% of the next $20,000, and 20% of earnings above $46,666 of Pre-Disability Earnings, ensuring that total benefits do not exceed these limits. For Partial Disability, benefits can reach 100% of Pre-Disability Earnings.

Subheading: When Income Protection Super, Standard and Premier end
ai_summary: Income Protection Super, Standard, and Premier policies terminate and the insurer's liability to pay benefits ends under several conditions: upon written cancellation by the Policy Owner or insured, non-payment of premiums, reaching specific policy anniversaries before the Life Insured turns 65 or 70, cancellation due to non-disclosure or misrepresentation, or upon the death of the Life Insured.

content: This Policy will be interpreted in accordance with New South Wales law and is subject to the exclusive jurisdiction of the Courts of Australia.
ai_summary: This insurance policy is governed by the laws of New South Wales and is exclusively subject to the jurisdiction of Australian courts, ensuring that any legal matters arising from the policy will be handled within this legal framework.

content: The Policy will be issued from TAL’s No. 1 Statutory Fund.
ai_summary: The policy will be issued from TAL's No. 1 Statutory Fund, ensuring compliance with regulatory requirements and providing a secure financial backing for policyholders. This fund is designed to support the obligations of the insurance policy, enhancing the stability and reliability of coverage offered.

content: Headings in the Plan conditions have been included to assist understanding but they do not alter how clauses are to be interpreted (unless stated otherwise or the context indicates the contrary). Where the context provides for it, words indicating the singular can be taken to mean the plural and vice versa.
ai_summary: Headings in the Plan conditions are provided for clarity and do not change the interpretation of clauses unless explicitly stated; additionally, singular terms may be interpreted as plural and vice versa when context allows.

content: Where improvements are made to Plan/Policy conditions without increasing the premium rates, these improved conditions will be included in your Policy. You will be notified of the changes and improvements via one or more of, notice in writing, on our website and via your adviser. In the unlikely event you and a Life Insured are unexpectedly disadvantaged in any way; the former wording of the condition will apply. If the Life Insured has any existing symptoms before an improved condition being included, the Life Insured will be assessed on the former wording of the condition (if applicable).
ai_summary: The policy guarantees that any improvements to Plan/Policy conditions, made without increasing premium rates, will be automatically included in your Policy, with notifications provided through written notice, the website, or your adviser. If you or a Life Insured are adversely affected by these changes, the previous policy wording will apply, and any existing symptoms prior to the inclusion of improved conditions will be assessed under the former terms.

content: The conditions of the Policy can be changed if required, but only if agreed to by both you and us. TAL reserves the right to apply an underwriting assessment to any Policy alteration that requires underwriting. Any change must be confirmed in writing by an authorised member of our staff. This section does not restrict our ability to change your Policy conditions as permitted under the Insurance Contracts Act if you fail to comply with the Duty of Disclosure.
ai_summary: Policy changes can be made with mutual agreement between you and TAL, subject to underwriting assessment for alterations requiring it. Any modifications must be confirmed in writing by an authorized representative, and this section does not limit TAL's right to change policy conditions as allowed under the Insurance Contracts Act in cases of non-compliance with the Duty of Disclosure.

Subheading: Obsolete criteria due to advancements in medical practice
content: Where a measure, scale, or other diagnostic technique or methodology used in this Policy Document (the obsolete term) has, in common usage, been superseded by a new measure, scale or other diagnostic technique or methodology (the new term), this Policy Document is to be read so the new term replaces the obsolete term unless to do so would materially disadvantage us.
ai_summary: This section stipulates that if any diagnostic measure or methodology referenced in the policy becomes outdated due to advancements in medical practice, the policy will automatically adopt the updated terminology, provided that such changes do not materially disadvantage the insurer. This ensures that the policy remains relevant and aligned with current medical standards.

content: If you wish to cancel your Policy you may be entitled to a refund of a proportion of the premium pursuant to our refund policy. If your Policy is structured through superannuation refunding premiums paid this payment is subject to preservation rules as required by superannuation law.
ai_summary: Policyholders can cancel their insurance policy and may receive a proportional refund of the premium according to the refund policy. For policies structured through superannuation, any refund is subject to preservation rules mandated by superannuation law.

content:
Stepped premiums
If you select stepped premiums, the amount you pay will generally increase at each Policy anniversary.
ai_summary: Stepped premiums refer to a payment structure where the premium amount increases at each policy anniversary. This option allows policyholders to anticipate rising costs over time, which may be beneficial for budgeting purposes, but it is essential to consider the long-term financial implications of these increasing charges.

Selecting level premiums means your premium amount is determined by the Life Insured's age at the start of the Plan and will only increase under specific conditions, such as adding new benefits, increasing the Benefit Amount, or changes in policy fees or discounts. Notably, level premiums will revert to stepped premiums on the anniversary before the Life Insured turns 65 or 70, depending on the policy terms. Any adjustments to coverage will use the Life Insured's current age for premium calculations.

content:
Changes in premiums
We can increase the rates or Policy fees (except for guaranteed level premiums for Life insurance). If we do increase our premium rates or Policy fees, you will be advised of the change before the increase taking effect. Premium rates are guaranteed not to change before the first anniversary of the Policy.
Your Policy cannot be singled out for an increase in premium rates because of an adverse change in the health or circumstances of the Life Insured once the risk is accepted.
ai_summary: The insurer reserves the right to increase premium rates or policy fees, excluding guaranteed level premiums for life insurance, with prior notification before the increase takes effect. Premium rates are guaranteed not to change until the first anniversary of the policy, and individual policies cannot be targeted for rate increases due to adverse changes in the health or circumstances of the insured after the risk has been accepted.

Subheading: Guaranteed level premium - Life insurance only
content:
Level premium rates for Life insurance are guaranteed not to increase until the Policy anniversary date before the Life Insured's:
• 65th birthday, where level premium to age 65 is selected; or
• 70th birthday where level premium to age 70 is selected,
except if due to any increase due to any tax, duty or charge introduced by government. Guaranteed level premium rates do not apply to Critical Illness, TPD or Income Protection insurance.
ai_summary: Guaranteed level premium rates for Life insurance remain unchanged until the policy anniversary prior to the Life Insured's 65th or 70th birthday, depending on whether the premium is set to age 65 or 70, respectively. However, these rates may be affected by any new government-imposed taxes, duties, or charges, and do not apply to Critical Illness, Total Permanent Disability (TPD), or Income Protection insurance.

content:
The Policy fee is included as part of each premium instalment. The Policy fee will be increased on each anniversary by the greater of the Indexation Factor or five per cent.
The policy fee changes with different premium frequency options:
ai_summary: The Policy fee is incorporated into each premium installment and will increase annually by the greater of the Indexation Factor or five percent. Additionally, the fee varies based on the chosen premium payment frequency.

content:
Premium frequency | Per instalment
---|---
Yearly | $77.00
Half-Yearly | $38.50
Quarterly | $21.00
Monthly | $7.00
ai_summary: The policy fee for this insurance is structured based on premium frequency, with costs set at $77.00 for yearly payments, $38.50 for half-yearly, $21.00 for quarterly, and $7.00 for monthly installments. This tiered payment system allows policyholders to choose a frequency that best suits their financial planning.

content:
Premiums are payable either yearly, half-yearly, quarterly or monthly. A frequency discount may apply for premiums paid half-yearly or yearly.
All premiums are payable in advance, by the due date shown in your Policy Schedule.
We will inform you of the premium payable in subsequent years before each Policy anniversary.
Only payments made quarterly, half-yearly and yearly can be made by cheque or BPAY®.
Where structured through superannuation and payments are made annually you may pay by rollover. Before deciding your payment structure, we recommend that you seek advice from your financial adviser.
ai_summary: Premiums can be paid yearly, half-yearly, quarterly, or monthly, with potential discounts for half-yearly or yearly payments. All premiums must be paid in advance by the due date specified in the Policy Schedule, and the insurer will notify policyholders of the premium amount for subsequent years prior to each Policy anniversary. Payments made quarterly, half-yearly, or yearly can be settled via cheque or BPAY®, while annual payments through superannuation may be made by rollover. It is advised to consult a financial adviser before selecting a payment structure.

Subheading: Non-payment or late payment of premium
content:
If we do not receive your premium payment by the due date, we will send you a notice and provide at least 30 days to pay the overdue premium. If we do not receive the payment of the premium by the date stated in the notice, your policy will be cancelled.
If this happens, you will need to apply to have your Policy reinstated if you continue to require the cover, or you may need to apply for a new Policy. Reinstatement is not guaranteed. We reserve the right to decline your application for reinstatement or offer reinstatement with altered terms and conditions.
ai_summary: If your premium payment is not received by the due date, you will receive a notice allowing at least 30 days to pay the overdue amount; failure to do so will result in policy cancellation. To reinstate your policy, you must apply, but reinstatement is not guaranteed and may be subject to altered terms and conditions.

content:
Premiums may be paid by:
• Direct debit;
• Credit card;
• Cheque; or
• BPAY® (Biller Code 7955)
• rollover where structured through TAL Super (yearly payments only).
If you select to pay your premiums by credit card, we may pass any related charges on to you.
ai_summary: Premiums for the insurance policy can be paid via direct debit, credit card, cheque, BPAY® (Biller Code 7955), or through a rollover structured with TAL Super for yearly payments only. If premiums are paid by credit card, any associated charges may be passed on to the policyholder.

content:
You are able to apply for reinstatement of a cancelled Policy within 12 months of the Policy being cancelled. To do this a reinstatement application must be completed. This application will be subject to Underwriting and extra information may be required. You will also be required to pay all premium arrears.
If the Policy has been cancelled for more than 12 months you can choose to apply for a new Policy, however, any new Policy application will be subject to full Underwriting.
We reserve the right to decline an application for reinstatement if you allow the Policy to repeatedly be cancelled due to non-payment, or on the basis of our Underwriting assessment.
We reserve the right to offer reinstatement with amendments to the terms of your cover.
If we reinstate your Policy or any Plan under it, no claim payment will be made for any:
• Injury or death which occurred while your Policy or Plan was cancelled; or
• Sickness, including Terminal Illness, that became apparent, while your Policy or Plan was cancelled.
In order for a claim to be paid, an event giving rise to a claim must occur while the Policy or Plan is in force.
Any application for reinstatement is subject to your duty of disclosure obligations.
This will not preclude you from making a claim for an event occurring after reinstatement if you disclosed this Injury or Sickness in your application for reinstatement and Underwriting accepted the reinstatement without an exclusion for that Injury or Sickness.
If a claim is payable after your premium is due, but before your Policy is cancelled, we will pay the claim in line with the respective Policy conditions. When this occurs, any outstanding premiums will be deducted from the claim amount.
ai_summary: Policyholders can apply for reinstatement of a cancelled policy within 12 months by completing a reinstatement application, which is subject to underwriting and requires payment of all premium arrears. If the cancellation exceeds 12 months, a new policy application must be submitted, also subject to full underwriting. Reinstatement may be declined for repeated non-payment or based on underwriting assessments, and any reinstated policy will not cover claims for injuries or illnesses that occurred during the cancellation period. Claims can be processed for events occurring after reinstatement if disclosed and accepted during the application. Outstanding premiums will be deducted from any claim payment if it occurs after the premium due date but before cancellation.

content: We understand the benefits of early engagement and we will support you through the claims process. If you wish to make a claim against the Policy, you must contact us at the earliest possible opportunity otherwise claim payments may be reduced to the extent the ability to assess the claim has been prejudiced by the delay in being able to adequately assess the claim. Our contact details can be found in Section 1 of this Policy Document. We will send you a claim form and explain in detail our requirements and what the next steps are.
ai_summary: To initiate a claim under the Policy, it is essential to notify us as soon as possible to avoid potential reductions in claim payments due to delays in assessment. We will provide you with a claim form and outline the necessary steps and requirements to support you through the claims process. For contact details, please refer to Section 1 of the Policy Document.

content: • proof of age (unless previously provided); and • proof of probate and a death certificate for death claims. You may also need to provide: • proof of Policy ownership; and • a signed discharge from an authorised person.
ai_summary: To notify us of a claim, you must provide proof of age (if not previously submitted) and, for death claims, a death certificate along with proof of probate. Additionally, you may need to supply proof of policy ownership and a signed discharge from an authorized person to process your claim effectively.

content: We must be satisfied of our liability to pay a benefit. Depending on the type of claim and your individual circumstances, you may be required to provide or undertake the following: • an examination of the Life Insured by a Medical Practitioner of our choice. This may involve imaging studies and clinical, histological and laboratory evidence; • examination by an appropriate specialist Medical Practitioner registered in Australia or New Zealand (or other country approved by us), not being the Life Insured, you, the Life Insured’s partner or spouse, or your partner or spouse; • proof that a surgical procedure was medically necessary and was the usual treatment for the underlying condition. For Terminal Illness Benefit claims, two Medical Practitioners must certify the extent of the Sickness or Injury, one being the specialist Medical Practitioner treating the condition and the other being a Medical Practitioner nominated by us who must confirm the diagnosis and life expectancy. For Income Protection you will be required to provide an initial medical attendants report and monthly medical certificates as determined by your case manager.
ai_summary: To validate a claim and determine liability for benefits, the insurer may require various medical assessments, including an examination by a designated Medical Practitioner, specialist evaluations, and proof of medical necessity for surgical procedures. For Terminal Illness Benefit claims, certification from two Medical Practitioners is necessary to confirm the diagnosis and life expectancy. Additionally, for Income Protection claims, an initial medical report and ongoing monthly medical certificates are required as specified by the case manager.

content: Whilst we assess your claim and unless we tell you otherwise, it is important to continue to pay premiums to ensure your cover is not cancelled.
ai_summary: During the claims assessment process, it is essential to continue paying your premiums to maintain your insurance coverage and prevent cancellation, unless otherwise instructed by the insurer.

content: For the purpose of: • Critical Illness insurance Death BuyBack Benefit; • Critical Illness insurance iReinstatement Option; or • TPD insurance Death Buy-Back Option, formal claim notification requirements consist of sufficient details of the claim to enable our assessment of the claim to commence including the Policy number, the condition claimed for and the date of the event or diagnosis.
ai_summary: Formal claim notification for Critical Illness insurance benefits, including the Death BuyBack Benefit, iReinstatement Option, and TPD insurance Death Buy-Back Option, must include essential details such as the Policy number, the specific condition being claimed, and the date of the event or diagnosis to initiate the assessment process.

content: Where we request an examination, assessment or financial information by a person we nominate, we will pay the cost for this service. Other costs which may be incurred for example, with completing claim forms, providing financial information as required, is not payable by us. An event giving rise to a claim must occur at a time while your insurance cover is in force and claim payments can only be made, start to accrue or continue while your cover is in place.
ai_summary: In the event of a claim, the insurer will cover costs for examinations, assessments, or financial information provided by a nominated individual, but will not reimburse expenses related to completing claim forms or providing additional financial data. Claims must arise during the active insurance coverage period, and payments can only be made while the policy remains in force.

content: For Income Protection insurance you will be advised if you are required to provide: • verification of the Life Insured’s Earnings stated in the application; and/or • verification of the Life Insured’s Earnings, Business Income and Business Expenses for the period before and after the event giving rise to your claim; • an audit of the Life Insured’s business and personal financial circumstances as often as is required. This may include auditing documents that constitute a legal requirement such as business taxation returns and profit and loss statements. We may require you to provide us with copies of the tax returns lodged with the ATO or other financial documentation which verifies your Earnings during a period for which we have paid an Income Protection benefit. We must receive this information by any reasonable timeframe we require.
ai_summary: For Income Protection insurance claims, you may need to provide verification of the Life Insured's earnings, business income, and expenses, both before and after the event causing the claim. This may include an audit of financial documents, such as tax returns and profit and loss statements, to confirm earnings during the benefit period. All requested information must be submitted within a reasonable timeframe as specified by the insurer.

content: You may be requested to provide the following information, as advised by your case manager, to support your claim: • a completed claim form; • the Policy Schedule; • proof of the event for which a claim is being made; • proof of payment, when a claim for reimbursement is being made;
ai_summary: To support your claim, you may need to provide specific documentation as requested by your case manager, including a completed claim form, the Policy Schedule, proof of the event prompting the claim, and proof of payment for reimbursement claims.

content:
We may recalculate the amount of the Income Protection benefit that we would have otherwise paid if your Earnings were averaged over the relevant claim period, and either:
• pay any underpayment of Income Protection Benefit(s);
• recover any overpaid Income Protection Benefit(s) in full; or
• reduce the amount of any future Income Protection Benefit(s) payable until the excess amount paid has been recovered.
For Income Protection Super, to comply with SIS Regulations at claim time you will be required to provide proof of earnings, even if your policy is Agreed Value. If required, the trustee will deduct any tax payable from any benefit payment made from the fund.
ai_summary: The insurer reserves the right to adjust the Income Protection benefit based on averaged earnings during the claim period, which may result in underpayments being compensated or overpayments being recouped from future benefits. For Income Protection Super claims, proof of earnings is mandatory to comply with SIS Regulations, even for Agreed Value policies, and any applicable taxes will be deducted from benefit payments by the trustee.

content: You and the Life Insured (if applicable) may be required to attend interviews by a member of our staff or someone appointed by us as often as is required to fully consider your claim.
ai_summary: Section 9 outlines that you and the Life Insured may need to participate in interviews conducted by our staff or appointed representatives as necessary to thoroughly evaluate your claim. This requirement ensures that all relevant information is gathered to facilitate the claims process.

content:
We may also request:
• access to details of the Life Insured’s previous medical consultations;
• assessment of current functional and vocational capacity by an appropriately qualified person selected by us; or
• obtaining information from various parties, subject to appropriate consent, including you and the Life Insured (if applicable), in relation to your claim, by a member of our staff or someone appointed by us, as often as is required. This may include, but not be limited to, details of any previous Injury or Sickness claims in relation to the Life Insured and details of previous occupation duties.
ai_summary: The insurer reserves the right to request access to the Life Insured's prior medical consultation records, an evaluation of their current functional and vocational capacity by a qualified professional, and relevant information from various parties, including the policyholder and the Life Insured, with appropriate consent. This may encompass details regarding any previous injury or sickness claims and past occupational duties, as needed to assess the claim effectively.

Subheading: Following advice of a Medical Practitioner
content: Claim payments will be dependent on the Life Insured following the reasonable advice of a Medical Practitioner. This includes following and actively participating in a recommended course of treatment and rehabilitation for any conditions on which the claim is being made. If the Life Insured is in Australia and becomes disabled and subsequently travels or resides outside Australia, claim payments will only be made if, in travelling or residing outside Australia, the Life Insured is following the advice of the treating Medical Practitioner. In this instance the case manager should be advised in advance of the Life Insured’s start date of travel. If the Life Insured is outside Australia and becomes disabled, the entitlement to claim may be suspended where we are unable to appraise the medical opinion or data relied upon by you. Consequently, the Life Insured may have to return to Australia for medical assistance for the claim to be assessed.
ai_summary: Claim payments are contingent upon the Life Insured adhering to the reasonable advice of a Medical Practitioner, including participation in recommended treatments and rehabilitation. If the Life Insured travels or resides outside Australia while disabled, claims will only be honored if they continue to follow medical advice and notify the case manager prior to travel. Additionally, if the Life Insured becomes disabled while abroad, claim entitlements may be suspended until they return to Australia for medical evaluation, as the insurer requires access to the relevant medical opinions and data.

Subheading: We may cancel a Policy for a fraudulent claim
content: If you make a fraudulent claim under your Policy or another policy you have with us, then we may cancel your Policy.
ai_summary: The insurance policy stipulates that if a policyholder submits a fraudulent claim, either under their current policy or any other policy with the insurer, the insurer reserves the right to cancel the policy. This condition underscores the importance of honesty in claims to maintain coverage.

Subheading: Your obligation regarding disability duration and severity
content: In providing you with this Policy, we have contracted to insure the Life Insured on the basis of the agreed cover. While we have accepted the risks associated with any potential loss, you and the Life Insured also have an obligation to mitigate your loss. You and the Life Insured must not knowingly contribute to the severity or longevity of the Life Insured’s disablement or your claim may not be accepted. We may reduce or decline to pay benefits during any period or periods of Total Disability or Partial Disability caused by failure to seek and follow medical advice or treatment. We may waive this requirement if, in the opinion of the Medical Practitioner, continued or future treatment would be of no benefit.
ai_summary: This policy requires both the policyholder and the Life Insured to actively mitigate any loss related to disability. If the Life Insured knowingly exacerbates their condition or fails to seek appropriate medical treatment, benefits may be reduced or denied. However, this requirement may be waived if a Medical Practitioner determines that further treatment would not be beneficial.

content: If you are legally competent to apply for a claim and your claim is accepted, all benefits will be paid to you or your legal personal representative. If your claim is accepted and you are judged to not be legally competent, we will pay any respective benefits to whomever we are legally permitted to make payments. If the Policy is owned by a trustee of a complying superannuation fund and your claim is accepted, all benefits will be paid to you or the trustee. We will not be liable to you for any loss you suffer (including consequential loss) caused by the fact that we are required by law to delay, block, freeze or refuse to process a transaction. If cover is provided under Income Protection Super, Standard or Premier and a claim is made for a period of disability of less than one month, it will be paid on a pro-rata basis. The payment will be made at a rate of 1/30th of the Benefit Amount for each day the Life Insured is Totally Disabled or Partially Disabled.
ai_summary: Claims will be paid to the policyholder or their legal representative if they are legally competent; otherwise, payments will be made to authorized individuals. For policies owned by a trustee of a complying superannuation fund, benefits will be directed to the trustee or the policyholder upon claim acceptance. The insurer is not liable for losses resulting from legal obligations that delay or block transactions. Additionally, for Income Protection Super, Standard, or Premier policies, claims for disabilities lasting less than one month will be compensated on a pro-rata basis at a rate of 1/30th of the Benefit Amount for each day of Total or Partial Disability.

content: If the age of the Life Insured has been incorrectly provided and the premium paid is lower than required, any claim payments that are subsequently made will be reduced. If the premium paid is higher than required, any overpaid premiums will be refunded. If the date of birth of the Life Insured has been incorrectly provided and the expiry date of the Policy would have been different had the correct date of birth been provided, then we may vary the Policy by changing its expiry date to the date that would have been the expiry date if the Policy had been based on the correct date of birth.
ai_summary: If the Life Insured's age is misstated, claim payments will be adjusted based on the correct premium amount; underpayments will lead to reduced claims, while overpayments will be refunded. Additionally, if the incorrect date of birth affects the Policy's expiry date, the insurer may amend the Policy to reflect the correct expiry date based on the accurate date of birth.

content:
Words used in this Policy Document that are capitalised have the following meaning:

**Accident** or **Accidental** means an accident caused wholly by violent, accidental, external and visible means.

**Activities of Daily Living (ADL)** are:
* Bathing – the ability to shower and bathe;
* Dressing – the ability to put on and take off clothing;
* Toileting – the ability to get on and off and use the toilet;
* Mobility – the ability to get in and out of bed and a chair; and
* Feeding – the ability to get food from a plate into the mouth.

**Attached** or **Attaching** means where under one Policy:
* Critical Illness insurance is added as a benefit to Life insurance;
* TPD insurance is added as a benefit to Life insurance; or
* TPD insurance is added as a benefit to Critical Illness insurance.
A payment under one will effect a corresponding reduction in the Benefit Amount payable under the other (Attached) insurance and a reduction in the total premium payable.

**Bed Confined** and **Bed Confinement** mean the Life Insured has been advised by a Medical Practitioner to remain in or near a bed for a substantial part of each day and under the continuous care of a Registered Nurse.
ai_summary: This section defines key terms used in the policy, including "Accident," which refers to incidents caused by external and visible means, and "Activities of Daily Living (ADL)," which encompass essential daily tasks such as bathing, dressing, toileting, mobility, and feeding. It also explains that "Attached" insurance refers to benefits like Critical Illness or Total Permanent Disability (TPD) insurance added to Life insurance, where claims on one will reduce benefits on the other. Additionally, "Bed Confined" indicates that the insured must remain in bed under a doctor's advice and continuous nursing care.

content:
**Benefit Amount** under Life insurance, Critical Illness insurance and TPD insurance is the respective lump sum amount shown in the Policy Schedule as applicable, after taking into account increases or reductions, applying:
* under the conditions of Life insurance, Critical Illness insurance and TPD insurance or option(s); or
* in line with a request by you that is agreed to by us.

**Benefit Amount** under Income Protection Super and any optional benefits, means the monthly benefit. The amount we pay you is determined by the option you have chosen (Agreed Value or Indemnity) at time of application.

If you have chosen ‘Indemnity’ as specified in your Policy Schedule, the initial benefit we will pay is the lesser of the following amounts:
* the Benefit Amount shown in your Policy Schedule, plus any increases under the Inflation Protection Benefit; and
* 75% of the first $26,666 ($320,000 pa) of monthly Earnings, 50% of the next $20,000 ($240,000 pa), to a monthly Benefit Amount of $30,000 ($360,000 pa), plus 20% of all monthly Earnings greater than $46,666 ($560,000 pa) earned by the Life Insured in the 12 month period immediately before the Sickness or Injury occurred,
less any Income Protection Adjustments if applicable.

Where you have an additional Benefit Amount for a Benefit Period of one or two years in addition to the maximum monthly Benefit Amount and you have chosen ‘indemnity’ as specified in your Policy Schedule, the initial benefit we will pay is the lesser of the following amounts:
* the Benefit Amount shown in your Policy Schedule plus any increases under the Inflation Protection Benefit; and
* 20% of all monthly Earnings greater than $46,666 ($560,000 pa), earned by the Life Insured in the 12 month period immediately before the Sickness or Injury occurred,
less any Income Protection Adjustments if applicable.

If you have chosen ‘Agreed Value’ as specified in your Policy Schedule, the Benefit Amount we will pay is the Benefit Amount shown in your Policy Schedule plus any increases under the Inflation Protection Benefit and less any Income Protection Adjustments if applicable.

If you have chosen ‘Indemnity’ as specified in your Policy Schedule, the initial benefit we will pay is the lesser of the following amounts:
* the Benefit Amount shown in your Policy Schedule, plus any increases under the Inflation Protection Benefit; and
* average Earnings in the 12 month period immediately before the Sickness or Injury occurred,
less any Income Protection Adjustments if applicable.
ai_summary: The **Benefit Amount** for Life, Critical Illness, and TPD insurance is a lump sum specified in the Policy Schedule, subject to adjustments based on policy conditions or requests. For Income Protection Super, the monthly benefit depends on the chosen option (Agreed Value or Indemnity); under Indemnity, it is the lesser of the Policy Schedule amount (plus inflation adjustments) or a percentage of monthly earnings, with specific caps based on earnings brackets. If Agreed Value is selected, the benefit is the Policy Schedule amount (plus inflation adjustments) minus any applicable adjustments.

content:
Where you have an additional Benefit Amount for a Benefit Period of one or two years in addition to the maximum monthly Benefit Amount and you have chosen 'Indemnity' as specified in your Policy Schedule, the initial benefit we will pay is the lesser of the following amounts:
• the Benefit Amount shown in your Policy Schedule plus any increases under the Inflation Protection Benefit;
• 20% of all monthly Earnings greater than $46,666 ($560,000 pa),
less any Income Protection Adjustments if applicable.

Business Expense Benefit under Business Expense Option means the monthly benefit shown in your Policy Schedule plus any increases under the Inflation Protection Benefit.

Benefit Period under Income Protection insurance (Super, Standard and Premier) means the period when disability benefits accrue. The maximum Benefit Period is shown in your Policy Schedule.
If the Benefit Period is one, two or five years, this is the maximum period that disability benefits will accrue for any one or related Sickness or Injury during the term of the Plan.
ai_summary: In the insurance policy, if an additional Benefit Amount for a Benefit Period of one or two years is selected with 'Indemnity,' the initial benefit paid will be the lesser of the specified Benefit Amount (including Inflation Protection) or 20% of monthly Earnings exceeding $46,666, minus any applicable Income Protection Adjustments. The Business Expense Benefit includes the monthly benefit plus Inflation Protection, while the Benefit Period defines the duration for which disability benefits accrue, with a maximum period specified in the Policy Schedule for any single or related Sickness or Injury.

content:
Blindness (permanent) means the total and irrecoverable loss of sight (whether aided or unaided) in both eyes as a result of Sickness or Injury to the extent that visual acuity in both both eyes, on a Snellen Scale after correction by a suitable lens is less than 6/60, or to the extent that the visual field is reduce to 20 degrees or less of arc.

Carer means the Life Insured provides everyday care to an Immediate Family Member due to disability or injury to enable them to live at home. The care must be necessary for medical reasons and have not been required before the Policy commencement. It must also be, in the opinion of a Medical Practitioner, likely to be required for a continuous period of at least six months.

Earnings means:
a) if the Life Insured does directly or indirectly, owns all or part of the business in which his or her work is performed (ignoring shares in publicly listed companies), their share of income earned in the conduct of the business or profession, less their share of business expenses necessarily incurred in the conduct of the business or profession; or
b) if the Life Insured is an employee (and paragraph (a) does not apply), salary, wages, superannuation, bonuses and any other income considered part of the Life Insured's remuneration package, earned by him or her for services performed.
Income paid from other disability income policies, retirement plans, lump sum disability payments, rental income and investment income are some examples of income we would not consider part of Earnings.

Exposure Prone Procedures means contact by the skin with sharp surgical instruments, needles, or splinters of bone or teeth in poorly visualised or confined body sites.
ai_summary: This section defines key terms relevant to the insurance policy: "Blindness (permanent)" refers to the total and irrecoverable loss of sight in both eyes, with specific visual acuity and field criteria; "Carer" describes the Life Insured providing necessary care to an Immediate Family Member due to disability or injury for at least six months; "Earnings" encompasses income from business ownership or employment, excluding certain disability and investment income; and "Exposure Prone Procedures" involves contact with sharp instruments in confined body areas.

content:
Gainful Occupation under Income Protection insurance (Super, Standard and Premier) means an occupation in which the Life Insured is working and as a result generates earnings.

Immediate Family Member means spouse, partner, de-facto, children, parents and siblings.

Indexation Factor is the percentage change in the Consumer Price Index (Weighted Average All Capital Cities) as last published by the Australian Bureau of Statistics in respect of the 12 month period finishing on 30 September of each year.
This factor will be determined at 30 November each year and applied, where indicated, for the following calendar year. If it is not published by 30 November, the Indexation Factor will be calculated based upon a retail price index we consider replaces it.
If the percentage change in the Consumer Price Index, or any substitute for it, is negative, the Indexation Factor will be taken as zero.

Injury means a bodily Injury suffered by the Life Insured.

Limb means an arm, leg, hand or foot. In respect of this definition, the hand or foot starts from the wrist or ankle joint, respectively.

Linked or Linking means the connection of two separate Policies whereby the payment under a Plan purchased under one Policy effects a corresponding reduction in the Benefit Amount payable under the other (Linked) Policy and a reduction in the total premium payable.

Long Term Leave is any leave period longer than four weeks such as any unpaid leave, maternity or paternity leave, a sabbatical, or leave taken to allow you to work for a charitable organisation.
ai_summary: This section defines key terms related to Income Protection insurance, including "Gainful Occupation," which refers to the job that generates earnings for the Life Insured, and "Immediate Family Member," encompassing close relatives. It explains the "Indexation Factor," which adjusts benefits based on the Consumer Price Index, with a zero value applied if the index change is negative. Additionally, it defines "Injury" as bodily harm to the Life Insured, "Limb" as specific body parts, and "Linked" policies, which connect two insurance policies affecting benefit amounts and premiums. Lastly, "Long Term Leave" refers to any leave exceeding four weeks, including unpaid, maternity, or sabbatical leave.

content:
Loss of Independent Existence (permanent) means Significant Cognitive Impairment or the total and irrecoverable loss of ability, due to Sickness or Injury, to perform at least two of the Activities of Daily Living without the physical assistance of another person.

Loss of use of a Single Limb (permanent) means the total and irrecoverable loss of use of one Limb.

Loss of use of Limbs (permanent) means the total and irrecoverable loss of use of two or more Limbs.

Loss of Sight in One Eye (permanent) means the total and irrecoverable loss of sight (whether aided or unaided) in one eye, as a result of Sickness or Injury to the extent that visual acuity in the eye, on a Snellen Scale after correction by a suitable lens is less than 6/60, or to the extent that the visual field is reduced to 20 degrees or less of arc.

Loss of Sight in One Eye and use of a Single Limb (permanent) means the total and irrecoverable Loss of use of a Single Limb and the permanent Loss of Sight in One Eye.
ai_summary: This section defines key terms related to permanent loss in insurance coverage: "Loss of Independent Existence" refers to significant cognitive impairment or the inability to perform at least two Activities of Daily Living without assistance; "Loss of use of a Single Limb" and "Loss of use of Limbs" denote the total and irrecoverable loss of function in one or more limbs, respectively; "Loss of Sight in One Eye" indicates the total and irrecoverable loss of vision in one eye, meeting specific visual acuity or field criteria; and "Loss of Sight in One Eye and use of a Single Limb" combines the criteria for both vision and limb loss.

content:
Medical Practitioner means a person who is legally qualified and registered as a Medical Practitioner, other than:
• you or the Life Insured;
• a business partner of you or the Life Insured; or
• an Immediate Family Member of you or the Life Insured.
If practising other than in Australia, the Medical Practitioner must be approved by us and have qualifications equivalent to Australian standards.
Note: Chiropractors, physiotherapists and alternative therapy providers are not regarded as Medical Practitioners.
ai_summary: A Medical Practitioner, for insurance purposes, is defined as a legally qualified and registered individual, excluding the policyholder, the Life Insured, their business partners, or immediate family members. If practicing outside Australia, the practitioner must be approved by the insurer and possess qualifications equivalent to Australian standards. Notably, chiropractors, physiotherapists, and alternative therapy providers do not qualify as Medical Practitioners under this definition.

content:
Normal Domestic Duties means:
• Cooking meals – to use kitchen and cooking utensils, appliances and equipment to prepare more than the most basic meals for oneself and/or others; and
• Cleaning the home – to use domestic appliances and equipment to clean and maintain a home and do laundry to basic standards; and
• Shopping for food – to shop for everyday household provisions; and
• Driving a car – the physical ability to drive a car; and
• Providing care for children and/or dependent adults (where applicable).
ai_summary: "Normal Domestic Duties" refers to essential household tasks covered by insurance, including cooking meals beyond basic preparation, cleaning and maintaining the home, shopping for everyday provisions, driving a car, and providing care for children or dependent adults. These definitions help clarify the scope of coverage related to domestic responsibilities in the context of insurance claims.

content:
Operating Loss means the Life Insured’s share of the Business Income less Business Expense, where:
• Business Income means the business turnover less the cost of goods sold (if applicable); and
• Business Expense means the expenses which are reasonable and necessarily incurred in generating Business Income, excluding salaries, fees, moneys or benefits paid to the Life Insured, depreciation, stock or items of a capital nature.
ai_summary: Operating Loss refers to the Life Insured's portion of Business Income after deducting Business Expenses. Business Income is calculated as total business turnover minus the cost of goods sold, while Business Expenses include reasonable costs incurred to generate that income, excluding salaries or benefits to the Life Insured, depreciation, and capital items.

content:
Own Occupation under Life insurance, Critical Illness insurance and TPD insurance is the occupation in which the Life Insured was working immediately before the Sickness or Injury causing disability.
If the Life Insured had been working in more than one occupation that meets these criteria, ‘Own Occupation’ will include all of those occupations.
ai_summary: "Own Occupation" in the context of Life, Critical Illness, and Total and Permanent Disability (TPD) insurance refers to the specific job the Life Insured was engaged in immediately prior to a Sickness or Injury that leads to disability. If the Life Insured held multiple qualifying occupations at that time, all such occupations will be considered under the definition of "Own Occupation."

content:
Own Occupation under Income Protection Premier is the occupation in which the Life Insured was working immediately before the Sickness or Injury causing disability, unless the Life Insured was unemployed or on sabbatical, long service, maternity or paternity leave for more than 12 months, in which case ‘Own Occupation’ will be any occupation the Life Insured is suited by training, education or experience.
If the Life Insured had been working in more than one occupation that meets these criteria, ‘Own Occupation’ will include all of those occupations.
ai_summary: "Own Occupation" under Income Protection Premier refers to the specific job the Life Insured held immediately prior to a Sickness or Injury that leads to disability. If the Life Insured was unemployed or on an extended leave (over 12 months), "Own Occupation" encompasses any job they are qualified for based on their training, education, or experience. Additionally, if the Life Insured had multiple relevant occupations, all such roles will be considered in defining "Own Occupation."

content:
Partial Disability and Partially Disabled under Income Protection insurance means that, solely because of a Sickness or Injury the Life Insured:
• is working in his or her Own Occupation or any Gainful Occupation, but in a reduced capacity; and
• is following the advice of a Medical Practitioner; and
• has suffered a reduction in the ability to generate Earnings.
ai_summary: Partial Disability and Partially Disabled, as defined in Income Protection insurance, refers to a situation where the insured individual, due to a Sickness or Injury, is working in their Own or any Gainful Occupation at a reduced capacity, is adhering to a Medical Practitioner’s advice, and has experienced a decrease in their ability to earn income.

content: Pre-Disability Earnings under Income Protection Super means the average Earnings of the Life Insured in the 12 month period immediately before the start of the Waiting Period.
ai_summary: Pre-Disability Earnings, as defined in the Income Protection Super policy, refer to the average earnings of the insured individual during the 12 months preceding the commencement of the Waiting Period. This figure is crucial for determining the benefits payable under the policy in the event of a disability.

content:
Pre-Disability Earnings under Income Protection (Standard and Premier) means:
If ‘Agreed Value’ is shown in your Policy Schedule, the highest average Earnings of the Life Insured for any consecutive 12 month period between the date three years before the Plan start date and the start of the Waiting Period.
If ‘Indemnity’ is shown in your Policy Schedule, the highest average Earnings of the Life Insured for any consecutive 12 month period in the three years immediately before the start of the Waiting Period.
When the Life Insured is disabled, Pre-Disability Earnings will be increased by the Indexation Factor, after every 12 consecutive monthly payments under Total Disability, Partial Disability or the Scheduled Injury Benefit.
ai_summary: Pre-Disability Earnings for Income Protection policies (Standard and Premier) are defined based on the type of coverage: if 'Agreed Value' is selected, it refers to the highest average earnings over any 12 consecutive months within three years prior to the plan start date; if 'Indemnity' is chosen, it applies to the highest average earnings over any 12 consecutive months in the three years before the Waiting Period. Additionally, these earnings will be adjusted by the Indexation Factor after every 12 monthly payments during periods of Total Disability, Partial Disability, or Scheduled Injury Benefit.

content:
Registered Nurse means a person who is legally qualified and registered as a nurse, other than:
• you or the Life Insured;
• a business partner of you or the Life Insured; or
• an Immediate Family Member of you or the Life Insured.
If practising other than in Australia, the Registered Nurse must have qualifications equivalent to Australian standards.
ai_summary: A Registered Nurse, as defined in this insurance document, is an individual legally qualified and registered as a nurse, excluding the policyholder, the Life Insured, their business partners, or immediate family members. If practicing outside Australia, the nurse must possess qualifications that are equivalent to Australian standards to be recognized under this policy.

content:
Rehabilitation Program means a program or plan:
• designed to assist the Life Insured in returning to work in their Own Occupation; and
• developed by an appropriately qualified vocational or occupational rehabilitation specialist.
General medical consultations and medical therapy consultations, including but not limited to, physiotherapy, psychotherapy and hydrotherapy, are excluded.
ai_summary: The Rehabilitation Program is a structured initiative aimed at helping the Life Insured return to their Own Occupation, created by a qualified vocational or occupational rehabilitation specialist. It is important to note that general medical consultations and therapies, such as physiotherapy, psychotherapy, and hydrotherapy, are not covered under this program.

content: Sickness means an illness or disease suffered by the Life Insured, as confirmed by a Medical Practitioner.
ai_summary: In insurance terms, "Sickness" refers to any illness or disease experienced by the Life Insured, which must be validated by a Medical Practitioner. This definition is crucial for determining coverage and claims related to health-related incidents under the policy.

content: Significant Cognitive Impairment means a deterioration or loss of intellectual capacity that results in a requirement for a full-time permanent caregiver.
ai_summary: Significant Cognitive Impairment refers to a decline in intellectual capacity that necessitates the ongoing support of a full-time permanent caregiver, which may impact eligibility for certain insurance benefits or coverage related to long-term care and disability.

content: Superlink or Superlinked means the connection of two separate Policies, one issued to the trustee of a superannuation fund and the other issued outside of superannuation. In the event no amount is payable under the superannuation Policy, or the amount payable is restricted, a payment may be made through the non-superannuation Policy, subject to the Life Insured meeting the terms and conditions of the non-superannuation Policy. The maximum benefits payable under both Policies will never exceed the amount that would have been payable under a single Policy outside of superannuation.
ai_summary: "Superlink or Superlinked" refers to the connection between two insurance Policies: one for a superannuation fund trustee and another outside of superannuation. If the superannuation Policy does not pay out or has limited benefits, the non-superannuation Policy may provide a payment, provided the Life Insured meets its terms. However, the total benefits from both Policies cannot exceed the maximum amount that would have been payable under a single non-superannuation Policy.

content: TAL Super means a plan within the Retail Division in the Mercer Super Trust (ABN 19 905 422 981) sponsored by TAL Services Limited.
ai_summary: TAL Super refers to a specific plan offered within the Retail Division of the Mercer Super Trust (ABN 19 905 422 981), which is sponsored by TAL Services Limited. This plan is designed to provide superannuation benefits to members, aligning with the regulatory framework governing superannuation in Australia.

content: Terminally Ill and Terminal Illness means an illness or condition where, after having regard to the current treatment or such treatment as the Life Insured may reasonably be expected to receive, the Life Insured has a life expectancy of less than 12 months. When Life Insurance is structured through superannuation, the Life Insured must also satisfy the SIS definition of Terminal Medical Condition.
ai_summary: "Terminally Ill" and "Terminal Illness" refer to a medical condition where, considering current and expected treatments, the Life Insured has a life expectancy of less than 12 months. In cases where life insurance is provided through superannuation, the Life Insured must also meet the SIS definition of a Terminal Medical Condition to qualify for benefits.

Subheading: Total and Permanent Disability and Totally and Permanently Disabled
content:
Total and Permanent Disability and Totally and Permanently Disabled when Any Occupation is shown in your Policy Schedule mean that:
* solely because of a Sickness or Injury, the Life Insured has not been working in their Own Occupation for three consecutive months and, in our opinion, after consideration of medical and any other evidence, is incapacitated to such an extent as to render the Life Insured unlikely ever to be able to work in their Own Occupation; or
* solely because of a Sickness or Injury, the Life Insured has suffered at least 25% impairment of Whole Person Function and has not been working in any occupation, and, in our opinion, after consideration of medical and any other evidence, is incapacitated to such an extent as to render the Life Insured unlikely ever to be able to work in any occupation for which they are reasonably suited by training, education or experience which would pay remuneration at a rate greater than 25% of the Life Insured’s Earnings during their last 12 months of work; or
* the Life Insured suffers:
    * Blindness (permanent); or
    * Loss of use of Limbs (permanent); or
    * Loss of Sight in One Eye and use of a Single Limb (permanent); or
* the Life Insured is totally and permanently unable to perform at least two of the five Activities of Daily Living without the physical assistance of another person; or
* where the Life Insured has been solely performing Normal Domestic Duties for more than 12 consecutive months immediately before the Sickness or Injury that gives rise to the claimable event:
    * the Life Insured has not been able to perform the Normal Domestic Duties for three consecutive months; and
    * in our opinion, after consideration of medical and any other evidence, is incapacitated to such an extent as to render the Life Insured unlikely ever to be able to perform all of the Normal Domestic Duties.
ai_summary: Total and Permanent Disability (TPD) is defined in the policy as the Life Insured being unable to work in their Own Occupation for three consecutive months due to Sickness or Injury, or having at least a 25% impairment of Whole Person Function and being unable to work in any occupation suited to their skills. Additional criteria include permanent blindness, loss of limb use, inability to perform two of five Activities of Daily Living without assistance, or being unable to carry out Normal Domestic Duties for three consecutive months after performing them for over a year. These conditions must be supported by medical evidence to qualify for benefits.

Subheading: Total and Permanent Disability and Totally and Permanently Disabled
content:
When cover is structured through superannuation, the Life Insured must also satisfy the SIS definition of Permanent Incapacity.
From the Policy anniversary before the Life Insured’s 65th birthday, ‘Total and Permanent Disability’, and ‘Totally and Permanently Disabled’ mean that the Life Insured suffers:
* Loss of Independent Existence (permanent); or
* Loss of use of Limbs (permanent); or
* Blindness (permanent).
ai_summary: In the context of superannuation-based coverage, 'Total and Permanent Disability' and 'Totally and Permanently Disabled' are defined for the Life Insured as experiencing permanent loss of independent existence, permanent loss of use of limbs, or permanent blindness, applicable from the policy anniversary preceding the Life Insured's 65th birthday. Additionally, the Life Insured must meet the SIS definition of Permanent Incapacity.

Subheading: Total and Permanent Disability and Totally and Permanently Disabled
content:
Total and Permanent Disability and Totally and Permanently Disabled when Own Occupation is shown in your Policy Schedule mean that:
* solely because of a Sickness or Injury, the Life Insured has not been working in their Own Occupation for three consecutive months and, in our opinion, after consideration of medical and any other evidence, is incapacitated to such an extent as to render the Life Insured unlikely ever to be able to work in their Own Occupation; or
* solely because of a Sickness or Injury, the Life Insured has suffered at least 25% impairment of Whole Person Function and has not been working in any occupation, and, in our opinion, after consideration of medical and any other evidence, is incapacitated to such an extent as to render the Life Insured unlikely ever to be able to work in any occupation for which they are reasonably suited by training, education or experience which would pay remuneration at a rate greater than 25% of the Life Insured’s Earnings during their last 12 months of work; or
* the Life Insured suffers:
    * Blindness (permanent); or
    * Loss of use of Limbs (permanent); or
    * Loss of Sight in One Eye and use of a Single Limb (permanent); or
* the Life Insured is totally and permanently unable to perform at least two of the five Activities of Daily Living without the physical assistance of another person; or
* where the Life Insured has been solely performing Normal Domestic Duties for more than 12 consecutive months immediately before the Sickness or Injury that gives rise to the claimable event:
    * the Life Insured has not been able to perform the Normal Domestic Duties for three consecutive months; and
    * in our opinion, after consideration of medical and any other evidence, is incapacitated to such an extent as to render the Life Insured unlikely ever to be able to perform all of the Normal Domestic Duties.
ai_summary: Total and Permanent Disability (TPD) is defined in the policy as the Life Insured being unable to work in their Own Occupation for three consecutive months due to a Sickness or Injury, or having at least a 25% impairment of Whole Person Function and being unable to work in any occupation for which they are reasonably suited. Additionally, TPD includes permanent conditions such as blindness, loss of limb use, or inability to perform at least two of the five Activities of Daily Living without assistance. For those solely performing Normal Domestic Duties, TPD applies if they cannot perform these duties for three consecutive months due to a qualifying Sickness or Injury.

Subheading: Total and Permanent Disability and Totally and Permanently Disabled
content:
From the Policy anniversary before the Life Insured’s 65th birthday, ‘Total and Permanent Disability’, and ‘Totally and Permanently Disabled’ mean that the Life Insured suffers:
• Loss of Independent Existence (permanent); or
• Loss of use of Limbs (permanent); or
• Blindness (permanent).
Total and Permanent Disability and Totally and Permanently Disabled when ‘ADL’ (Activities of Daily Living) is shown in your Policy Schedule mean that the Life Insured:
• is totally and permanently unable to perform at least two of the five Activities of Daily Living without the physical assistance of another person; or suffers:
– Blindness (permanent); or
– Loss of use of Limbs (permanent); or
– Loss of Sight in One Eye and use of a Single Limb (permanent); or
– Significant Cognitive Impairment.
