When cover is structured through superannuation, the Life Insured must also satisfy the SIS definition of Permanent Incapacity.
ai_summary: Total and Permanent Disability (TPD) is defined for the Life Insured as suffering from permanent loss of independent existence, loss of use of limbs, or blindness. Additionally, if 'ADL' (Activities of Daily Living) is specified, TPD means being unable to perform at least two of the five ADLs without assistance, or experiencing permanent blindness, limb loss, loss of sight in one eye with limb use, or significant cognitive impairment. For coverage through superannuation, the Life Insured must also meet the SIS definition of Permanent Incapacity.

content:
Waiting Period means the period of time between the Life Insured suffering disability and disability benefits starting to accrue.
If the Life Insured does not consult a medical practitioner concerning the Sickness or Injury causing disability within seven days of the Sickness starting or the Injury occurring, the Waiting Period will start when the Life Insured consults a Medical Practitioner.
ai_summary: The Waiting Period is the duration between the onset of a disability and the commencement of disability benefits. If the Life Insured fails to consult a medical practitioner within seven days of the onset of the Sickness or Injury, the Waiting Period will instead begin upon their first consultation with a medical practitioner.

Subheading: War or an act of war
content: War or an act of war means armed aggression, whether declared or not, by a country or organisation, resisted by any other country or organisation.
ai_summary: In insurance terms, "War or an act of war" refers to armed aggression, regardless of whether it is officially declared, conducted by a country or organization, and met with resistance from another country or organization. This definition is crucial for understanding coverage limitations and exclusions related to war-related incidents in insurance policies.

content: Whole Person Function means where a payment depends on the Life Insured meeting criteria based on the Whole Person Function, the calculation is to be based on the current edition of the American Medical Association publication entitled Guides to the Evaluation of Permanent Impairment until an equivalent Australian guide, sanctioned by the Australian Medical Association, has been produced, at which time the calculation in the relevant Australian guide will apply.
ai_summary: Whole Person Function refers to the assessment criteria for determining insurance payments based on the Life Insured's condition, utilizing the current American Medical Association's Guides to the Evaluation of Permanent Impairment until an equivalent Australian guide is available, at which point the Australian guide will take precedence for calculations.

content:
Total Disability and Totally Disabled under Income Protection insurance means that, solely because of a Sickness or Injury, the Life Insured is following the advice of a Medical Practitioner and:
• is not working in any Gainful Occupation and is unable to perform one or more duties necessary to generate income in the Life Insured’s Own Occupation; or
• is not working in any Gainful Occupation and has suffered a reduction of 80% or more in the ability to generate Earnings in the Life Insured’s Own Occupation; or
• is unable to perform the duties necessary to generate income for more than 10 hours per week and;
– for Income Protection Super and Standard, is not in any Gainful Occupation; or
– for Income Protection Premier, his or her Earnings are less than their Pre-Disability Earnings.
ai_summary: Total Disability and Totally Disabled, as defined in Income Protection insurance, refers to the Life Insured's inability to work in any Gainful Occupation due to Sickness or Injury, as advised by a Medical Practitioner. This condition is met if the individual cannot perform essential duties in their Own Occupation, experiences an 80% or greater reduction in earnings, or is unable to work more than 10 hours per week, with specific conditions for different Income Protection plans regarding earnings relative to pre-disability levels.

content: Where Income Protection Super has been selected (as indicated in the Policy Schedule), the Life Insured must also satisfy the SIS definition of Temporary Incapacity or Permanent Incapacity.
ai_summary: In the context of Income Protection Super, as specified in the Policy Schedule, the Life Insured is required to meet the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act (SIS) definitions of either Temporary Incapacity or Permanent Incapacity to qualify for benefits under the policy.

content: Underwriting is a process by which we assess risks associated with accepting your application for insurance. The Underwriting process is based on the life to be insured’s health and other relevant factors, such as occupation, pursuits and income.
ai_summary: Underwriting is the process of evaluating the risks involved in accepting an insurance application, taking into account the applicant's health, occupation, activities, and income. This assessment is crucial for determining the terms and conditions of the insurance coverage offered.

content: Unemployed and Unemployment mean that the Life Insured is not employed or working in any Gainful Occupation. It does not include sick leave, sabbatical, long service, maternity or paternity leave.
ai_summary: In the context of this insurance document, "Unemployed" and "Unemployment" refer specifically to the Life Insured's status of not being engaged in any Gainful Occupation, excluding periods of sick leave, sabbatical, long service, maternity, or paternity leave. This definition is crucial for determining eligibility for benefits related to unemployment within the policy.

content: The following definitions have been reproduced from SIS. You should be aware that if any of these definitions are changed in SIS, the corresponding definition reproduced here will be obsolete and replaced by the amended definition in SIS.
ai_summary: Section 10.2 outlines that the definitions provided are sourced from the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act (SIS), and emphasizes that any changes to these definitions in SIS will render the current definitions obsolete, necessitating updates to maintain accuracy and compliance.

content: Permanent Incapacity in relation to a member of a superannuation fund means ill-health (whether physical or mental), where the trustee is reasonably satisfied that the member is unlikely, because of the ill-health, to engage in gainful employment for which the member is reasonably qualified by education, training or experience.
ai_summary: Permanent Incapacity, as defined for members of a superannuation fund, refers to a state of ill-health—either physical or mental—where the trustee believes the member is unlikely to return to gainful employment suited to their qualifications due to this condition. This definition is crucial for determining eligibility for benefits related to permanent incapacity under the fund's insurance provisions.

content: Temporary Incapacity in relation to a member of a superannuation fund who has ceased to be gainfully employed (including a member who has ceased temporarily to receive any gain or reward under a continuing arrangement for the member to be gainfully employed), means ill-health (whether physical or mental) that caused the member to cease to be gainfully employed but does not constitute Permanent Incapacity.
ai_summary: Temporary Incapacity refers to a situation where a member of a superannuation fund is unable to engage in gainful employment due to ill-health, either physical or mental, but does not qualify as Permanent Incapacity. This definition encompasses members who have temporarily stopped receiving income from their employment arrangements.

A Terminal Medical Condition for a superannuation fund member is defined as an illness or injury certified by two registered medical practitioners, including at least one specialist, indicating that the member is likely to die within 24 months from the certification date, with the certification period still active.

content:
Adult onset insulin dependent diabetes mellitus diagnosed after age 30 means the diagnosis after the age of 30 of Type 1 diabetes mellitus for which insulin is required for survival.
Angioplasty means the actual undergoing of Coronary Artery Angioplasty to correct a narrowing or blockage of one or more coronary arteries.
Aortic Surgery means surgery to repair or correct an aortic aneurysm, an aortic dissection, an obstruction of the aorta, a coarctation of the aorta or traumatic Injury to the aorta. For the purpose of this definition, aorta means the thoracic (ascending) and abdominal (descending) aorta but not its branches.
ai_summary: Section 10.3 defines critical illness events relevant to insurance coverage, including adult onset insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus diagnosed after age 30, which requires insulin for survival; angioplasty, referring to the procedure to correct coronary artery blockages; and aortic surgery, which involves repairing conditions affecting the aorta, such as aneurysms or dissections. These definitions are crucial for determining eligibility and benefits related to critical illness claims.

Aplastic Anaemia (requiring treatment) is defined as a condition of bone marrow failure leading to anaemia, neutropenia, and thrombocytopenia that necessitates medical intervention. Treatment options covered include blood product transfusions, marrow stimulating agents, immunosuppressive agents, or bone marrow transplantation.

Subheading: Benign Brain Tumour (resulting in irreversible neurological deficit)
content:
Benign Brain Tumour (resulting in irreversible neurological deficit) means a non-cancerous tumour in the brain, pituitary gland or spinal cord, resulting in an irreversible neurological deficit which has caused:
• a permanent impairment of at least 25% of the Whole Person Function; or
• the Life Insured to be totally and permanently unable to perform any one of the Activities of Daily Living.
The presence of the underlying tumour must be confirmed by CT Scan, MRI or other imaging studies. Cysts, granulomas, vascular aneurysms or haematomas are not covered.
ai_summary: A Benign Brain Tumour (resulting in irreversible neurological deficit) is defined as a non-cancerous tumour in the brain, pituitary gland, or spinal cord that leads to a permanent impairment of at least 25% of Whole Person Function or total and permanent inability to perform any Activities of Daily Living. Coverage requires confirmation of the tumour through CT Scan, MRI, or other imaging studies, while conditions such as cysts, granulomas, vascular aneurysms, or haematomas are excluded from coverage.

content: Blindness (permanent) means the total and irrecoverable loss of sight (whether aided or unaided) in of both eyes as a result of Sickness or Injury to the extent that visual acuity in both eyes, on a Snellen Scale after correction by suitable lens is less than 6/60, or to the extent that the visual field is reduce to 20 degrees or less of arc.
ai_summary: Permanent blindness is defined as the total and irreversible loss of sight in both eyes, whether with or without corrective lenses, due to sickness or injury. This condition is characterized by a visual acuity of less than 6/60 on the Snellen Scale or a visual field reduced to 20 degrees or less.

content:
Cancer (excluding early stage cancers) means the presence of one or more malignant tumours, including lymphoma (including Hodgkin’s and non Hodgkin’s disease), leukaemia, multiple myeloma and malignant bone marrow disorders that are characterised by the uncontrolled growth and spread of malignant cells and the invasion and destruction of normal tissue beyond the basement membrane.
The following cancers are excluded:
• Tumours which are histologically described as premalignant or show the malignant changes of carcinoma in situ (including cervical dysplasia, HSIL, LSIL, CIN III and lower).
ai_summary: In this insurance document, "Cancer (excluding early stage cancers)" refers to malignant tumors, including lymphoma, leukaemia, multiple myeloma, and malignant bone marrow disorders, characterized by uncontrolled cell growth and tissue invasion. Excluded from coverage are tumors classified as premalignant or those with malignant changes of carcinoma in situ, such as cervical dysplasia and various grades of cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN).

content:
• Carcinoma in situ of the breast, unless a procedure is required for;
– the removal of the entire breast; or
– there is breast conserving surgery together with radiotherapy or chemotherapy.
These procedures must be considered by the treating doctor to be the appropriate and necessary treatment.
• Carcinoma in situ of the testicle, unless a procedure is required for the removal of the entire testicle.
The procedure must be performed specifically to arrest the spread of malignancy, and be considered the appropriate and necessary treatment.
• Melanomas, unless:
– there is evidence of metastases; or
– the melanoma is at least Clark level 3; or
– the melanoma is showing signs of ulceration; or
– the melanoma is greater than 1.0mm maximum thickness as determined by examination using the Breslow method.
• All hyperkeratosis, intraepidermal carcinomas, basal cell carcinomas and squamous cell carcinomas of skin unless it has spread to the bone, lymph node or another organ.
• Chronic lymphocytic leukaemia less than Rai stage 1.
• Prostate cancer, unless:
– it has a Gleason score of 6 or more; or
– major interventional therapy including radiotherapy, chemotherapy, biological response modifiers or any major surgical treatment has been required to arrest the spread of malignancy.
ai_summary: This section defines exclusions for cancer coverage, specifying that certain conditions are not covered unless specific treatment criteria are met. Carcinoma in situ of the breast and testicle is excluded unless surgical removal is deemed necessary by the treating doctor to prevent malignancy spread. Melanomas are excluded unless they show metastases, are at least Clark level 3, exhibit ulceration, or exceed 1.0mm in thickness. Additionally, skin cancers like hyperkeratosis and basal cell carcinomas are excluded unless they have metastasized. Chronic lymphocytic leukaemia below Rai stage 1 and prostate cancer with a Gleason score below 6 are also excluded unless significant treatment is required to manage the disease.

content:
Carcinoma In Situ means the Life Insured has a carcinoma in situ, characterised by a focal autonomous new growth of carcinomatous cells, which has not yet resulted in the invasion of normal tissues. ‘Invasion’ means an infiltration and/or active destruction of normal tissue beyond the basement membrane. The tumour must be classified as Tis according to the TNM staging method or FIGO Stage 0.
Only Carcinoma In Situ of the following sites is covered:
• Breast
• Cervix Uteri (Excluded are Cervical Intraepithelial Neoplasia (CIN) classifications including CIN-1 and CIN-2).
• Corpus Uteri
• Fallopian Tube (the tumour must be limited to the tubal mucosa)
• Ovary
• Penis
• Perineum
• Prostate
• Testicle
• Vagina
• Vulva
Note: FIGO refers to the staging method of the Fédération Internationale de Gynécologie et d’Obstétrique.
ai_summary: Carcinoma In Situ refers to a localized carcinoma characterized by abnormal cell growth that has not invaded surrounding tissues, classified as Tis under the TNM staging system or FIGO Stage 0. Coverage is limited to specific sites, including the breast, cervix uteri (excluding certain CIN classifications), corpus uteri, fallopian tube (limited to tubal mucosa), ovary, penis, perineum, prostate, testicle, vagina, and vulva.

content: Cardiomyopathy (permanent) means a disease of heart muscle causing the heart muscle to enlarge and become weaker, resulting in significant permanent cardiac impairment to the degree of at least Class 3 of the New York Heart Association functional classification system.
ai_summary: Cardiomyopathy (permanent) is defined as a disease that leads to the enlargement and weakening of the heart muscle, resulting in significant and lasting cardiac impairment classified as at least Class 3 according to the New York Heart Association functional classification system. This definition is crucial for determining eligibility and benefits related to cardiac-related insurance claims.

Subheading: Chronic Kidney Failure (requiring transplantation or dialysis)
content: Chronic Kidney Failure (requiring transplantation or dialysis) means end-stage renal failure presenting as chronic irreversible failure of both kidneys to function, resulting in renal transplantation or the permanent requirement for renal dialysis.
ai_summary: Chronic Kidney Failure, as defined in the insurance document, refers to end-stage renal failure characterized by the irreversible loss of function in both kidneys, necessitating either a kidney transplant or ongoing renal dialysis. This definition is crucial for determining eligibility for coverage and benefits related to treatment options under the insurance policy.

Subheading: Chronic Liver Failure (resulting in permanent symptoms)
content: Chronic Liver Failure (resulting in permanent symptoms) means end-stage liver failure resulting in permanent jaundice, ascites and/or encephalopathy.
ai_summary: Chronic Liver Failure (resulting in permanent symptoms) is defined as end-stage liver failure characterized by permanent symptoms such as jaundice, ascites, and/or encephalopathy, which may impact eligibility for certain insurance benefits or claims related to severe liver conditions.

Subheading: Chronic Lung Failure (requiring permanent oxygen therapy)
content:
Chronic Lung Failure (requiring permanent oxygen therapy) means end-stage lung disease with a consistent pulmonary function test result of:
• FEV1 less than 40% predicted; and
• a DLCO less than 40% predicted; and
• requiring permanent oxygen therapy.
ai_summary: Chronic Lung Failure (requiring permanent oxygen therapy) is defined as end-stage lung disease characterized by a forced expiratory volume (FEV1) of less than 40% of the predicted value, a diffusing capacity of the lungs for carbon monoxide (DLCO) of less than 40% of the predicted value, and the necessity for ongoing oxygen therapy. This definition is crucial for determining eligibility for specific insurance benefits related to severe respiratory conditions.

content: Coma (of specified severity) means a state of unconsciousness with no reaction to external stimuli or internal needs, resulting in a documented Glasgow Coma Scale of 8 or less, for a continuous period of at least 72 hours.
ai_summary: "Coma (of specified severity)" is defined as a state of unconsciousness where the individual shows no response to external stimuli or internal needs, characterized by a Glasgow Coma Scale score of 8 or lower, and must persist for a minimum duration of 72 hours to qualify for insurance coverage.

content: Congenital Blindness (permanent) means a congenital, total and permanent loss of sight in both eyes whether aided or unaided.
ai_summary: Congenital Blindness (permanent) refers to a total and irreversible loss of sight in both eyes that is present from birth, regardless of whether vision aids are used. This definition is crucial for determining eligibility for specific insurance benefits related to vision impairment.

content: Congenital Deafness (permanent) means a congenital, total and permanent loss of hearing in both ears whether aided or unaided.
ai_summary: Congenital Deafness (permanent) refers to a total and irreversible loss of hearing in both ears that is present from birth, regardless of whether hearing aids are used. This definition is crucial for determining eligibility for specific insurance benefits related to hearing impairments.

content: Coronary Artery Bypass Surgery means bypass grafting performed to correct or treat coronary artery disease.
ai_summary: Coronary Artery Bypass Surgery refers to the surgical procedure of bypass grafting aimed at correcting or treating coronary artery disease, which may be covered under certain insurance policies depending on the specific terms and conditions outlined in the plan.

content: Dementia including Alzheimer’s Disease (permanent) means the unequivocal diagnosis of dementia by a consultant neurologist or geriatrician. The diagnosis must confirm dementia or Alzheimer’s Disease due to permanent failure of brain function with associated cognitive impairment. A Mini-Mental State Examination score of 24 or less out of 30 or evidence from another neuropsychometric test that is acceptable to us is required.
ai_summary: Dementia, including Alzheimer's Disease (permanent), is defined as a definitive diagnosis by a consultant neurologist or geriatrician, confirming permanent brain function failure and cognitive impairment. To qualify for coverage, a Mini-Mental State Examination score of 24 or lower, or acceptable results from another neuropsychometric test, is required.

content: Diagnosed Benign Brain Tumour means a non-cancerous tumour in the brain, pituitary gland or spinal cord giving rise to symptoms of increased intracranial pressure such as papilloedema, mental symptoms, seizures, sensory impairment and motor impairment. The presence of the underlying tumour must be confirmed by CT Scan, MRI or other imaging studies. Cysts, granulomas, vascular aneurysms and haematomas are not covered.
ai_summary: A Diagnosed Benign Brain Tumour refers to a non-cancerous growth in the brain, pituitary gland, or spinal cord that causes symptoms like increased intracranial pressure, seizures, and sensory or motor impairments, confirmed through imaging studies such as CT scans or MRIs. Notably, conditions like cysts, granulomas, vascular aneurysms, and haematomas are excluded from coverage.

content: Disseminated Intravascular Coagulation (pregnancy related) means, due to pregnancy, an over-activation of the coagulation and fibrinolytic system occurs, resulting in thrombosis, consumption of platelets and coagulation factors causing life threatening haemorrhage from multiple sites.
ai_summary: Disseminated Intravascular Coagulation (pregnancy related) refers to a serious condition triggered by pregnancy, characterized by excessive activation of the coagulation and fibrinolytic systems, leading to thrombosis and the depletion of platelets and coagulation factors, which can result in life-threatening hemorrhages from various sites. This definition is crucial for understanding coverage and risk assessment related to pregnancy complications in insurance policies.

content: Down’s Syndrome means a specific genetic impairment caused by an extra chromosome 21, which causes mental retardation and physical abnormalities.
ai_summary: Down's Syndrome is defined as a genetic condition resulting from an extra chromosome 21, leading to intellectual disabilities and physical anomalies. This definition is crucial for insurance policies as it may influence coverage decisions, eligibility for benefits, and the assessment of related medical needs.

content: json Section_Title : 10 Definitions , Subheading : Early Stage Chronic Lymphocytic Leukaemia , content : Early Stage Chronic Lymphocytic Leukaemia means the presence of chronic lymphocytic leukaemia diagnosed as Rai Stage 0, which is defined to be in the blood and bone marrow only. , content_label : text , Section_Title : 10 Definitions , Subheading : Early Stage Melanoma (excluding Melanoma In Situ) , content : Early Stage Melanoma (excluding Melanoma In Situ) means the presence of one or more malignant melanomas which are TNM classification T1aN0M0. Melanomas which are stage Tis or less are excluded. , content_label : text , Section_Title : 10 Definitions , Subheading : Early Stage Prostate Cancer , content : Early Stage Prostate Cancer means the presence of a malignant tumour confined within the prostate, which is histologically described as TNM Classification T1 or a Gleason Score of either 2, 3, 4 or 5 where major medical interventionalist therapy is not required. , content_label : text , Section_Title : 10 Definitions , Subheading : Eclampsia of Pregnancy , content : Eclampsia of Pregnancy means the occurrence of high blood pressure during pregnancy resulting in coma or grand mal seizures and delivery of the foetus regardless of the gestational age. , content_label : text , Section_Title : 10 Definitions , Subheading : Ectopic Pregnancy , content : Ectopic Pregnancy means a fertilised ovum has implanted outside the uterine cavity resulting in the rupturing or haemorrhaging of a fallopian tube, which results in a laparotomy or laparoscopic surgery removing the involved fallopian tube. , content_label : text , Section_Title : 10 Definitions , Subheading : Encephalitis and Meningitis (resulting in permanent neurological deficit) , content : Encephalitis and Meningitis (resulting in permanent neurological deficit) means the unequivocal diagnosis of encephalitis or meningitis where the condition is characterised by severe inflammation of the brain or the meninges o
ai_summary: Section 10 Definitions outlines specific medical conditions relevant to insurance coverage, including Early Stage Chronic Lymphocytic Leukaemia (Rai Stage 0), Early Stage Melanoma (TNM classification T1aN0M0), Early Stage Prostate Cancer (confined to the prostate with TNM Classification T1 or Gleason Score 2-5), Eclampsia of Pregnancy (high blood pressure leading to seizures or coma), Ectopic Pregnancy (implantation outside the uterus requiring surgical intervention), and Encephalitis and Meningitis (resulting in permanent neurological deficits). Each definition specifies the medical criteria necessary for claims related to these conditions.

Subheading: Major Head Trauma (with permanent neurological deficit)
content:
means Accidental head Injury resulting in neurological deficit causing:
• at least a permanent 25% impairment of Whole Person Function; or
• the Life Insured being totally and permanently unable to perform any one of the Activities of Daily Living.
ai_summary: Major Head Trauma (with permanent neurological deficit) refers to an accidental head injury that leads to a significant and lasting impairment, defined as either a minimum of 25% impairment of Whole Person Function or the Life Insured's total and permanent inability to perform any one of the Activities of Daily Living.

The term "Major Organ Transplant" refers to either undergoing a transplant or being placed on a waiting list by a specialist Medical Practitioner at a recognized transplant unit for specific organs, including bone marrow, kidney, heart, lung, liver, pancreas, or small bowel, as recognized by the Transplantation Society of Australia and New Zealand. Transplants of other organs, parts of organs, or tissue are not covered under this definition.

Subheading: Medically-Acquired HIV (contracted from a medical procedure or operation)
ai_summary: Medically-Acquired HIV refers to accidental infection with HIV contracted in Australia through medically necessary events, such as blood transfusions, organ transplants, assisted reproductive techniques, or procedures by licensed health professionals, after the policy's inception. Coverage requires notification and proof from a Statutory Health Authority confirming the infection's medical acquisition. Exclusions apply for infections acquired through sexual activity or drug use not prescribed by a medical professional. Additionally, no benefits will be provided if a cure or vaccine approved by the Australian Government is available and not utilized by the insured.

Subheading: Meningococcal Disease (resulting in significant permanent impairment)
content:
means the unequivocal diagnosis of meningococcal septicaemia resulting:
• in at least a permanent 25% impairment of Whole Person Function; or
• the Life Insured being totally and permanently unable to perform any one of the Activities of Daily Living.
ai_summary: Meningococcal Disease, as defined in the insurance document, refers to a confirmed diagnosis of meningococcal septicaemia that results in either a permanent impairment of at least 25% of Whole Person Function or the Life Insured's total and permanent inability to perform any one of the Activities of Daily Living. This definition is crucial for determining eligibility for benefits related to significant permanent impairment.

Subheading: Multiple Sclerosis (with multiple episodes of neurological deficit and persisting neurological abnormalities)
content:
means a disease characterised by demyelination in the brain and/ or spinal cord. Multiple Sclerosis must be unequivocally diagnosed. There must be more than one episode of well-defined neurological deficit with persisting neurological abnormalities.
Neurological investigations such as lumbar puncture, MRI (Magnetic Resonance Imaging) evidence of lesions in the central nervous system, evoked visual responses, and evoked auditory responses are required to confirm diagnosis.
ai_summary: Multiple Sclerosis (MS) is defined as a disease marked by demyelination in the brain and/or spinal cord, requiring an unequivocal diagnosis. To qualify for coverage, there must be multiple episodes of well-defined neurological deficits accompanied by persistent neurological abnormalities, supported by neurological investigations such as lumbar puncture, MRI evidence of lesions in the central nervous system, and evoked visual and auditory responses.

content: means the unequivocal diagnosis of muscular dystrophy.
ai_summary: This section defines "muscular dystrophy" as the unequivocal diagnosis of the condition, which is crucial for determining eligibility for related insurance benefits and coverage. Understanding this definition is essential for policyholders seeking claims or support related to muscular dystrophy under their insurance plan.

content:
means infection, after the inception of the Policy, with Hepatitis B or C where the infection is acquired as a result of:
• an accident arising out of the life insured’s normal occupation; or
• a malicious act of another person or persons arising out of the Life Insured’s normal occupation.
Proof of new Hepatitis B or C infection must be registered within six months of the accident or malicious act.
Any incident giving rise to a potential claim must:
• be reported to the relevant authority or employer within seven days of the incident;
• be reported to us with proof of the incident within 30 days after the incident; and
• be supported by a negative Hepatitis B or C test taken within seven days of the incident.
The infection must manifest itself within six months of the accident or malicious act. The infection must not have arisen from a deliberately, self-inflicted or induced cause or from sexual activity (whether as part of normal occupational duties or otherwise), or from the use of drugs not medically prescribed for the Life Insured.
This Critical Illness Event will not apply and no payment will be made where a cure has become available or where a medical treatment is developed and approved which makes these viruses inactive and non-infectious, or results in there being little or no impact on life expectancy.
Hepatitis B or C infection transmitted by any other means including sexual activity or recreational intravenous drug use is excluded.
ai_summary: Occupationally-Acquired Hepatitis B or C refers to infections contracted after the policy's inception due to accidents or malicious acts related to the insured's occupation. Claims must be reported within seven days to the relevant authority and within 30 days to the insurer, accompanied by proof and a negative test within seven days. The infection must manifest within six months, and exclusions apply for self-inflicted causes, sexual activity, and non-prescribed drug use. Coverage will not apply if a cure or effective treatment is developed that renders the viruses inactive or minimally impactful on life expectancy.

content:
Occupationally-Acquired HIV means infection with the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) where such infection arose from an Accident relating to the occupation of the Life Insured, subject to the following conditions:
• the Accident must have occurred after the inception of the Policy;
• within 30 days of the Accident, proof of its occurrence must be registered with TAL including:
– tests taken by a Medical Practitioner within seven days after the Accident which resulted in a sero-negative HIV result; and
– documents confirming any relevant authority was notified within seven days of the Accident.
The infection must manifest itself as a sero-positive HIV test result within six months of the reported occurrence. The infection must not have arisen from a deliberately, self-inflicted or induced cause or from sexual activity (whether as part of normal occupational duties or otherwise), or from the use of drugs not medically prescribed for the Life Insured.
We reserve the right to obtain independent tests and investigations, including the taking of blood samples from the Life Insured.
This Critical Illness Event will not apply and no payment will be made where a cure has become available or where the infected person does not take any vaccine available before the Critical Illness Event. ‘Cure’ means an Australian Government-approved treatment which renders the HIV inactive and non-infectious, or results in there being little or no impact on life expectancy.
‘Vaccine’ means a preparation approved by the Australian Government and recommended for use by the Government authority to produce immunity to the HIV.
ai_summary: Occupationally-Acquired HIV refers to HIV infection resulting from an occupational accident occurring after the policy's inception, with specific conditions for coverage. The insured must report the accident to TAL within 30 days, including medical tests confirming a sero-negative result within seven days and notification to relevant authorities. The infection must be confirmed as sero-positive within six months, and exclusions apply for self-inflicted causes, sexual activity, or non-prescribed drug use. Coverage is void if a cure or vaccine approved by the Australian Government is available and not utilized. TAL reserves the right to conduct independent testing and investigations.

content: Open Heart Surgery means the undergoing of open chest surgery for the surgical treatment of a cardiac defect, cardiac aneurysm or benign cardiac tumour.
ai_summary: Open Heart Surgery refers to the surgical procedure involving open chest surgery to address cardiac defects, aneurysms, or benign tumors. In the context of insurance, this definition is crucial for determining coverage eligibility and benefits related to surgical treatments for specific heart conditions.

content:
Out of Hospital Cardiac Arrest means a loss of cardiac output that is not associated with any medical procedure and is due to
• cardiac asystole; or
• ventricular fibrillation with or without ventricular tachycardia.
The cardiac arrest must occur outside of a hospital and be documented by electrocardiogram.
ai_summary: "Out of Hospital Cardiac Arrest" refers to a loss of cardiac output occurring outside of a hospital setting, specifically due to cardiac asystole or ventricular fibrillation (with or without ventricular tachycardia). For insurance purposes, this condition must be documented by an electrocardiogram and is not linked to any medical procedures.

content: Paralysis (permanent) means the total and permanent loss of function of two or more limbs through Sickness or Injury causing permanent damage to the nervous system. This includes, but is not limited to, quadriplegia, paraplegia, diplegia and hemiplegia.
ai_summary: Permanent paralysis is defined as the total and irreversible loss of function in two or more limbs due to sickness or injury that results in permanent nervous system damage. This condition encompasses various forms of paralysis, including quadriplegia, paraplegia, diplegia, and hemiplegia, which may be relevant for insurance coverage and claims.

content:
Parkinson’s Disease (permanent) means the unequivocal diagnosis of degenerative idiopathic Parkinson’s disease caused by degeneration of the nigrostriatal system and as characterised by the clinical manifestation of one or more of the following:
• rigidity;
• tremor; and
• akinesia.
All other types of Parkinsonism are excluded (e.g. secondary to medication).
ai_summary: Parkinson’s Disease (permanent) is defined as a confirmed diagnosis of degenerative idiopathic Parkinson’s disease, specifically resulting from the degeneration of the nigrostriatal system, and is characterized by symptoms such as rigidity, tremor, and akinesia. It is important to note that other forms of Parkinsonism, including those induced by medication, are not covered under this definition.

content: Pneumonectomy means the undergoing of surgery to remove an entire lung. This treatment must be deemed the most appropriate treatment and medically necessary.
ai_summary: Pneumonectomy refers to the surgical procedure involving the removal of an entire lung, which must be considered the most appropriate and medically necessary treatment for coverage under the insurance policy.

content: Primary Pulmonary Hypertension means the unequivocal diagnosis of Primary Pulmonary Hypertension with right ventricular enlargement established by investigations including cardiac catheterisation.
ai_summary: Primary Pulmonary Hypertension is defined as a confirmed diagnosis characterized by right ventricular enlargement, which must be established through diagnostic procedures such as cardiac catheterization. This definition is critical for determining coverage and benefits related to treatment under the insurance policy.

Subheading: Progressive and Debilitating Motor Neurone Disease
content: Progressive and Debilitating Motor Neurone Disease means the unequivocal diagnosis of a progressive form of debilitating Motor Neurone Disease.
ai_summary: The term "Progressive and Debilitating Motor Neurone Disease" refers to a definitive diagnosis of a progressive variant of Motor Neurone Disease, which is crucial for determining eligibility for specific insurance benefits related to this condition.

Subheading: Severe Burns (covering at least 20% of the body’s surface area)
content:
Severe Burns (covering at least 20% of the body’s surface area) means tissue Injury caused by thermal, electrical or chemical agents causing third degree or full thickness burns to at least:
• 20% of the body surface area as measured by the Lund and Browder Body Surface Chart;
• 50% of both hands, requiring surgical debridement and/ or grafting; or
• 50% of the face, requiring surgical debridement and/or grafting.
ai_summary: Severe Burns, as defined in this insurance document, refer to third-degree or full-thickness tissue injuries affecting at least 20% of the body’s surface area, as assessed by the Lund and Browder Body Surface Chart. Coverage also applies to burns involving 50% of both hands or 50% of the face, provided these injuries necessitate surgical debridement and/or grafting.

Subheading: Severe Crohn’s Disease (requiring permanent immunosuppressive medication)
content: Severe Crohn’s Disease (requiring permanent immunosuppressive medication) means the unequivocal diagnosis of Crohn’s disease that has failed to be controlled by standard therapy including cortisone treatment, which requires permanent immunosuppressive medication.
ai_summary: Severe Crohn’s Disease, as defined in this insurance document, refers to a definitive diagnosis of Crohn’s disease that remains uncontrolled despite standard treatments, including cortisone therapy, necessitating the ongoing use of immunosuppressive medication. This definition is crucial for determining eligibility for specific insurance benefits related to chronic illness management.

Severe Diabetes Mellitus is defined as a condition confirmed by a certified consultant endocrinologist, where the insured has experienced at least two specific complications due to diabetes: severe diabetic retinopathy with visual acuity of 6/36 or worse in both eyes, severe diabetic neuropathy causing motor or autonomic impairment, diabetic gangrene requiring surgery, or severe diabetic nephropathy resulting in chronic irreversible renal impairment with a corrected creatinine clearance below 28ml/min (CKD stage 4).

content:
Severe Osteoporosis means, where the bone mineral density has a T-score of less than -2.5 (ie 2.5 standard deviations below the adult mean for bone density) measured in at least two sites by dual-energy x-ray densitometry (DEXA) or quantitative CT scanning is consistent with severe osteoporosis with:
• at least two vertebral body fractures occurring before the age of 65; or
• Fracture of the neck of the femur.
ai_summary: Severe Osteoporosis is defined as a condition where bone mineral density has a T-score of less than -2.5, assessed at two or more sites using DEXA or quantitative CT scanning. This diagnosis is applicable if the individual has experienced at least two vertebral body fractures before age 65 or a fracture of the neck of the femur, which may impact insurance coverage and benefits related to osteoporosis treatment and management.

Subheading: Severe Ulcerative Colitis (requiring permanent immunosuppressive medication)
content: Severe Ulcerative Colitis (requiring permanent immunosuppressive medication) means the unequivocal diagnosis of ulcerative colitis that has failed to be controlled by standard therapy including cortisone treatment, which requires permanent immunosuppressive medication.
ai_summary: Severe Ulcerative Colitis, as defined in this insurance document, refers to a definitive diagnosis of ulcerative colitis that is unmanageable through standard treatments, including cortisone, necessitating the ongoing use of immunosuppressive medication. This condition is critical for determining coverage eligibility and benefits related to treatment under the policy.

Severe Rheumatoid Arthritis (with significant impairment) is defined as a confirmed diagnosis of rheumatoid arthritis that has not responded to all treatment regimens, resulting in a permanent reduction of Whole Person Function by at least 25%. Alternatively, it can be diagnosed unequivocally by a Rheumatologist if there is a six-week history involving specific joint areas, bilateral and symmetrical joint swelling, typical joint deformity, and at least two additional criteria such as morning stiffness or positive serological markers. Degenerative osteoarthritis and other forms of arthritis are excluded from this definition.

content: Spina Bifida Myelomeningocele means a defective closure of the spinal column resulting in a neural tube deficit with a resultant meningomyelocele or meningocele and associated neurological deficit confirmed by a Medical Practitioner. Spina bifida occulta is excluded.
ai_summary: Spina Bifida Myelomeningocele is defined as a condition involving an incomplete closure of the spinal column, leading to a neural tube defect characterized by meningomyelocele or meningocele, along with neurological deficits confirmed by a Medical Practitioner. It is important to note that spina bifida occulta is not covered under this definition.

content: Stillbirth means the foetal death in utero after at least 20 weeks gestation and confirmed by a Medical Practitioner. Elective pregnancy termination is excluded.
ai_summary: Stillbirth is defined as the death of a fetus occurring in utero after a minimum of 20 weeks of gestation, with confirmation required from a Medical Practitioner. It is important to note that elective pregnancy terminations are not covered under this definition.

content: Subacute Sclerosing Panencephalitis means the unequivocal diagnosis of this disorder (only covered under the Child’s Critical Illness insurance).
ai_summary: Subacute Sclerosing Panencephalitis is defined as a definitive diagnosis of the disorder, which is specifically covered under the Child’s Critical Illness insurance policy. This coverage highlights the importance of a clear diagnosis for eligibility under the terms of the insurance plan.

content:
Stroke (resulting in neurological deficit) means a cerebrovascular event producing neurological deficit. This requires clear evidence on a CT, MRI or similar, appropriate scan or investigation that a stroke has occurred and of infarction of brain tissue, intracranial and/ or subarachnoid haemorrhage.
The following are not covered:
• Transient ischaemic attacks
• Non-stroke related reversible neurological deficit
• Cerebral symptoms due to migraine
• Cerebral injury resulting from trauma or hypoxia
• Vascular disease affecting the eye or optic nerve
• Ischaemic disorders of the vestibular system
• Migraine
• Hypoxic events.
ai_summary: In insurance terms, a "Stroke (resulting in neurological deficit)" is defined as a cerebrovascular event that leads to neurological impairment, confirmed by imaging tests such as CT or MRI showing brain tissue infarction or hemorrhage. Exclusions from coverage include transient ischemic attacks, reversible neurological deficits not related to stroke, migraine-related cerebral symptoms, trauma or hypoxia-related cerebral injuries, and specific vascular diseases affecting the eye or vestibular system.

content:
Tetralogy of Fallot means an anatomical defect with severe or total right-ventricular outflow tract obstruction and a ventricular septal defect allowing right- ventricular deoxygenated blood to bypass the pulmonary artery and enter the aorta directly.
The diagnosis must be supported by an echocardiogram, and invasive surgery must be performed to correct the condition.
ai_summary: Tetralogy of Fallot is defined as a congenital heart defect characterized by significant obstruction of the right-ventricular outflow tract and a ventricular septal defect, enabling deoxygenated blood to flow from the right ventricle directly into the aorta instead of the pulmonary artery. For insurance coverage, a diagnosis must be confirmed through an echocardiogram, and corrective invasive surgery is required to treat the condition.

content:
Transposition of Great Vessels means a congenital heart defect where the aorta arises from the right ventricle and the pulmonary artery from the left ventricle.
The diagnosis must be based on an echocardiogram and invasive surgery must be performed to correct the condition.
ai_summary: Transposition of Great Vessels is defined as a congenital heart defect characterized by the aorta originating from the right ventricle and the pulmonary artery from the left ventricle. For insurance coverage, diagnosis must be confirmed via echocardiogram, and corrective invasive surgery is required to treat the condition.

content: Triple Vessel Angioplasty means the actual undergoing for the first time of coronary artery Angioplasty to correct a narrowing or blockage of three or more coronary arteries within the same procedure. In the event that not all coronary arteries can be corrected in a single procedure and a second procedure is required, a benefit will be payable provided the second procedure occurs no more than two months after the first.
ai_summary: Triple Vessel Angioplasty refers to the initial procedure of coronary artery angioplasty aimed at correcting narrowing or blockage in three or more coronary arteries simultaneously. If a subsequent procedure is necessary to address remaining blockages, insurance benefits will be provided, provided this second procedure occurs within two months of the first.

ai_summary: TAL is a prominent life insurance provider in Australia, safeguarding nearly 4 million individuals with $2.9 billion in in-force premiums and supported by a workforce of over 1,600 employees.

Notable accolades include the 2015 Life Insurance Company of the Year at the Asia Pacific Banking and Finance Insurance Awards, multiple Adviser Choice Risk Awards for Disability Income Products, and the 2017 Trauma Product of the Year at the AFA/Strategic Insight Platinum Awards. Additionally, the provider was acknowledged for outstanding value in income protection insurance by CANSTAR and Money Magazine, underscoring its commitment to quality service and customer experience in the insurance sector.

Subheading: We're here when our customers need us most. In 2017, we:
content:
Paid a record $1.6 billion in claims (about $31 million each week)
Supporting more than 25,000 Australians and their families
60% of the claims we paid were for living benefits, helping our customers during their recovery from illness or injury
ai_summary: In 2017, TAL paid a record $1.6 billion in claims, averaging approximately $31 million weekly, to support over 25,000 Australians and their families. Notably, 60% of these claims were for living benefits, providing essential financial assistance to customers during their recovery from illness or injury.
